title.rendered: Take It To The Lord In Prayer

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Felt prompt to re share this devotion I emailed in 2008 in preparation for part 2 I was meditating upon this morning. Continue to keep my brother in your prayers.

Isaiah 37:1-14, “And Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers, and read it; and Hezekiah went up to the house of the LORD, and spread it before the LORD”

We live in a time where if anything is going to happen, it will not happen by chance but because there are people praying. When you look at the marriages on the rocks, families in chaos, schools in trouble, the government having challenges, kidnappings left and right, murders, suicides, and accidents you name it, is on the rise, how will we stand? There is a constant fear of what might happen even before it happens. Fear of tomorrow cripples so many.

King Hezekiah was faced by a situation where he was threatened too but by Sennacherib king of Assyria. Now Assyria was known to be a powerful kingdom and they had subdued many nations and even breaking their gods. Coming to King Hezekiah, they knew that Judah was protected by God but they tried to bring fear by saying God will not save them when Assyria attacks, they said Isaiah 37:10, “Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you, saying, “Jerusalem shall not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria”. This is no different from what the devil whispers in our ears every day. The devil will accuse you of making mistakes with no avenues of second chances or victory. He could be right that you blew it, but who told the devil our victory is based on what we did?  It’s based on the one who laid aside His majesty, giving up everything, suffering at the hands of those He had created, taking all the guilt and shame when He died and rose again. Today He has called us His own and He is seated on the right hand of God the Father making intercession for us. He says, “When you pray, pray in my name” because He knows how it feels to be lied about. You cannot cry over what could have been and how it could have been, you cannot also continue to plead with the enemy to leave you alone, you need to stand and tell him of whom you are in Christ. If he reminds you of your past, remind him of his future. Hezekiah has been told that there is no way God will come to his rescue but instead of calling his servants to help him weep, he takes the time to go to the house of God to pray. You understand what you are going through better than anyone else; you have a better way of presenting your case to the Lord in prayer as you pray earnestly, constantly, effectively.

He received bad news but did not take it as the final word. Whatever the enemy whispers in our ears is not final, God has a final say in a situation. As long as He has not spoken against it, we should continue to bring it to Him. He received the letter, read it and thought, “I have to take this to the Lord in prayer”, Isaiah 37:14, “and Hezekiah went up to the house of the LORD, and spread it before the LORD”. Stop covering up what you are going through or trying to fix it in your own strength, like Hezekiah, take it to the Lord in prayer and spread it out as it is. Remember this hymn “What a friend we have in Jesus? take a look at the lyrics

What a friend we have in Jesus, All our sins and griefs to bear! What a privilege to carry Ev’rything to God in prayer! Oh, what peace we often forfeit, Oh what needless pain we bear, All because we do not carry, Ev’rything to God in prayer!

Have we trials and temptations? Is there trouble anywhere? We should never be discouraged, Take it to the Lord in prayer: Can we find a friend so faithful Who will all our sorrows share? Jesus Knows our every weakness, Take it to the Lord in prayer.

Are we weak and heavy laden, Cumbered with a load of care? Precious Savior, still our refuge; Take it to the Lord in prayer: Do thy friends despise, forsake thee? Take it to the Lord in prayer; In His arms He’ll take and shield thee; Thou wilt find a solace there.

Just as Hezekiah refused to take the enemy’s word as final, we too can do the same today. You know what your needs are, take it to the Lord in prayer and spread it like it is. Be blessed Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

The word “holiness” carries with it some unwanted baggage, thanks to “religion.” In the East, to be a holy man means to sit naked with your legs crossed, and having folks give you money in return for your blessing. Some holy men sit on poles for twenty years (Pillar Saints). Others stay off poles but they stay away from any contact with a sinful world, in a holier-than-thou legalism. Others live in monasteries, and have a vow of silence. Much of the Church doesn’t live on poles or have a holier than thou attitude. They do however live in a monastery – one without walls. They, too, have a vow of silence. Few have physical contact with the world. Their association with humanity is strictly confined to the Church. Fellowship is what they have on Wednesday nights, Sunday mornings and Sunday nights. The are salt among salt, light among light.

True holiness is the opposite of the above. It does mean that we cut ourselves off from the sin, but not from the sinners. True holiness is to be like Jesus – “separate from sin” and yet He was accused of being a “friend of sinners.” The Scriptures admonish us with these thought-provoking words: “I wrote to you in an epistle not to company with fornicators: Yet not altogether with the fornicators of this world, or with the covetous, or extortioners, or with idolaters; for then must you needs go out of the world. But now I have written to you not to keep company, if any man that is called a brother be a fornicator, or covetous, or an idolater, or a railer, or a drunkard, or an extortioner; with such an one no not to eat” (1Corinthians 5:9-10). Can you see what the Bible is saying? If we separate ourselves from sinners, we won’t be able to reach them with the gospel of salvation. The only ones we are told to separate ourselves from are hypocrites. Look at these wonderful words from George MacLeod of Scotland: “I simply argue that the cross should be raised at the center of the marketplace as well as on the steeple of the church. I am recovering the claim that Jesus was not crucified in a cathedral between two candles, but on a cross between two thieves; on the town’s garbage heap; at a crossroad, so cosmopolitan they had to write His title in Hebrew and Latin and Greek . . . at the kind of a place where cynics talk smut, and thieves curse, and soldiers gamble. Because that is where He died. And that is what He died for. And that is what He died about. That is where church-men ought to be and what church-men ought to be about.”

There is nothing “spiritual” about being holy. It just means a separation from sin. God is holy – He is sinless, and we too are called to be holy: “But as He who has called you is holy, so you be holy in all manner of conversation” (1 Peter 1:15) See Isaiah 6:3; Revelation 15:4. See also Romans 6:19, 22; Ephesians 1:4; Titus 1:8; 1 Peter 1:15.

It’s as simple as this – God has given us an umbrella in the Savior to shelter us from the reign of His wrath. God has given the covering, and we are told to stay under that covering of holiness. How may we best do that? We do this by reading God’s Word daily and by the cultivation of a tender conscience. By having an obedient heart, and by living in the fear of God.

The next time you try to witness to someone you know isn’t right with God, and he suddenly says, “Oh, I’ve been born again. I know the Lord,” ask him if he is “living in holiness.” More than likely he will say that he is. Then call his bluff. Ask him to define “holiness.” As he is straining his brain to come up with a definition, say, The Bible says, “Without holiness, no man shall see the Lord” This means that we should be separated from sin and the world and then ask him if he thinks he’s a good person. More than likely he will, so take the time to take him through the Moral Law. Blessings Pastor Phil.

title.rendered: When You Can’t Get What You want

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 39:16 So she kept his garment with her until his master came home. 17 Then she spoke to him with words like these, saying, “The Hebrew servant whom you brought to us came in to me to mock me; 18 so it happened, as I lifted my voice and cried out, that he left his garment with me and fled outside.”  19 So it was, when his master heard the words which his wife spoke to him, saying, “Your servant did to me after this manner,” that his anger was aroused. 20 Then Joseph’s master took him and put him into the prison

One of the most frightening things in my opinion is the damage a tongue can do. James speaks extensively about the tongue, how deadly it is left unattended. Have we not been given one mouth to speak and two ears to listen instead of the other way round? Yet we find that a lot of people are  quick to speak and slow to listen; They jump to conclusions without facts.

Joseph here finds himself in Potiphar’s house, he is serving well even his master can sense something different about him. Of all the servants he had, Joseph was unique; he sensed the Lord was with him. And whatever Joseph did in Potipha’rs house, God blessed it. Then here comes Potiphar’s wife who eyes this young man, wanting something from him, his innocence, and his purity before the Lord. And when she could not get what she wanted, Joseph vowed to be pure before God, she takes something from him to accuse him of something bigger, attempted rape. Now that is a serious accusation.

When you don’t get what you want, how do you deal with it? When I was a teenager, I liked this girl and wanted to go out with her. She seemed to hang out with this other guy more. Instead of accepting the reality of things, I began to slander their names, making other people believe what I said about them that I knew not be true. What damage that was I regret till today. That is something that happens even today, it’s easy to slander, lie about someone, tarnish their names because they have something you want but can’t have. Instead of accepting things the way they are, you turn to frustrate them, lie about them, find people to convince to side with you against such a person. That is what Potiphar’s wife did, because she could not accept the fact that she could not have what she wanted, she purposed in her heart to destroy Joseph by lying about his intentions. She knew that if she could not destroy him in any other way, her tongue would be sufficient. After all, who were they going to believe?

There are certain people if someone told you that they did this and that, you would probably not believe them because you already know the character of that person.  That may not mean they could never do what they are accused of, their nature, their lifestyle would suggest otherwise. Then there are those whom if they are told you of what they did, you would be prompt to say something like this, “I would not be surprised if they did such and such a thing”. Well in Joseph’s case, he is accused of attempted rape, his master is not even stopping to say or even think , “that doesn’t sound like Joseph” so as to find facts and truths to turn upon, the other servants seem to be quiet and it doesn’t seem he’s been given a chance to defend himself. The wife was the bigger influence on the verdict. God who had blessed him and been with him seemed silent when he needed him the most yet knows the whole truth. Who will stand with Joseph? His name is tarnished, he has lost his job, he is going to jail, he is further away from his dream because of false accusation and it’s all because of the tongue that would not accept that she could not have what she wanted and therefore turned to destroy another life. The bible says in Proverbs 12:22, “Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, But those who deal truthfully are His delight”. Are you being driven right now to destroy another person’s life through lies because you are unable to get what you want and if you can’t get, then you feel it’s not fair for the other person to have it, be blessed, or prosper while you are miserable? Are you getting people to rally behind you to accept what you say about someone without sharing the true facts or having them do the same? James 1:26 “If anyone among you thinks he is religious, and does not bridle his tongue but deceives his own heart, this one’s religion is useless.” Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Examine yourselves as to whether you are in the faith

content.rendered:
Good morning,

I would like to share a gospel presentation. The bible says in 2Corinthians 13: 5 to “Examine yourselves as to whether you are in the faith. Test yourselves. Do you not know yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you?-unless indeed you are disqualified”, though long, it’s very vital to help you evaluate if you are in the faith. If you are, forward this message to all your friends, family members you’ve been dying to reach with the gospel but you’ve been afraid of how to approach them. This is a great tool God can use to bring them to the saving knowledge of Jesus Christ. I go out of the streets to witness, I’ve done a video witnessing to reach people in Africa and face book, I’ve used email to reach my extended families. I have trusted God to use any of these tools to reach and save the lost. If God could use a donkey to speak, He can use anything. So read it, be blessed and share it. Blessings Ev

Examine yourselves as to whether you are in the faith

Almost everyone thinks they are a good person…But the question you should be asking is,”Am I good enough to go to Heaven?” The way to find out is to ask yourself if you have obeyed the Ten Commandments. Most people say, “Well, I’ve broken one or two, but nothing too serious, like murder, etc.”, With tender conscious review these commandments and see if you’ve kept any of them 1. “You shall have no other gods before Me.” Have you always put God first in your life? Jesus said to love God with all your heart, mind, soul, and strength– so much, that your love for your parents, brothers and sisters, friends, and even your own life is like hatred compared to your love and devotion for God. Have you ever failed to put Him first in your life? 2. “You shall not make for yourself any idol.” Who is God to you? Is he only a god of love and mercy who would never judge anyone and never cast anyone into Hell? If that’s your god, then you’re right. Your god couldn’t cast anyone into Hell because he doesn’t exist. He’s a figment of your imagination. You’ve created a god in your own mind that you’re more comfortable with. You may call it your “personal belief,” but God calls it idolatry. It’s the oldest sin in the Book, and the Bible warns that idolaters will not inherit the kingdom of heaven. 3. “You shall not take the name of God in vain.” Have you ever used God’s name as a curse word? If you have, you’ve taken the holy name of God– who gave you your life, your family, and everything precious to you– and used it as a filthy, four-letter word. Hitler’s name wasn’t even despised enough to be used as a curse word! If you have used God’s holy name in that manner, you are a blasphemer and the Bible says “God will not hold him guiltless who takes the name of the Lord in vain.” 4. “Remember the Sabbath Day, to keep it holy.” God commands that we set aside one day in seven. Have you ever been guilty of breaking this Commandment?

5. “Honor your father and your mother.” Have you always honored your parents in a way that’s pleasing in the sight of God? Ask Him to remind you of the sins of your youth. You may have forgotten them, but God hasn’t. 6. “You shall not murder.” Jesus warned “Whoever is angry with his brother without cause, is in danger of judgment,” (Matthew 5:22) and the Bible says, “He who hates his brother is a murderer,” (1 John 3:15). God sees hatred in the heart to be as wicked as murder. We can violate His Law by attitude and intent. 7. “You shall not commit adultery.” Jesus warned,” You have heard…’You shall not commit adultery.’ But I say to you that whoever looks at a woman to lust for her has already committed adultery with her in his heart. Have you ever looked at another person with lust? The Bible says that adulterers and fornicators (those who have had sex before marriage) will not enter the kingdom of heaven. 8. “You shall not steal.” Have you ever stolen anything (even if it was something small)? The value of the thing stolen doesn’t matter; petty theft is still theft. Have you ever taken anything that belonged to someone else (from the office, school, parents, etc.)? If you have, that makes you a thief. 9. “You shall not lie.” Have you ever told a lie? Then you are a liar. How many murders do you have to commit to be a murderer? Just one. If you have told even one lie, that makes you a liar. The Bible warns that all liars will have their part in the Lake of Fire (Revelation 21:8). You may not think deceitfulness is a serious sin, but God does. 10. “You shall not covet.” This means we should never desire anything that belongs to another person. Not their house, nor their car, nor their money, nor their wife, nor their lifestyle, nor anything that belongs to our neighbor Who of us can say we are not guilty of breaking these Commandments? This is what the Bible means when it says, “All have sinned and fall short of the Glory of God.” Can you see your predicament? You are guilty of sinning against God Himself, and, because you have a conscience, (con-with, science-knowledge) you have sinned “with knowledge.” Isn’t it true that every time you lied, stole, or lusted, etc., you knew it was wrong? Does the fact that you have sinned against God scare you? It should.  You have actually angered Him by your sin. The Bible says His wrath abides on you, that you are an “enemy of God in your mind through wicked works.” Perhaps you think God is good and because of his goodness He will overlook your sins? But if you knew of a human judge who turned a blind eye to the crimes of a guilty rapist… would you describe him as “good” judge? God could never be a corrupt judge. He will punish all the rapists, murderers, and thieves… But he won’t stop there. He will also punish all liars, the lustful, adulterers, idolaters, and blasphemers. God does not want you to perish. He is rich in mercy and compassion, and has provided a way for you to be forgiven. He has invited you to come to Him for a full pardon and receive the free gift of Eternal Life. You cannot earn it, and you do not deserve it, but God is offering it to you as proof of His love for you. Imagine you are standing in front of a judge, guilty of multiple serious crimes. All the evidence has been presented and there is no doubt about your guilt. Your apologies and good works cannot erase your crimes; therefore you must be punished. The fine for your crime is $250,000 or imprisonment, but you don’t have two pennies to rub together. The judge is about to pass sentence when someone you don’t even know steps in and pays your fine for you! The court accepts the money and declares that you are free to go. The law has been satisfied, your debt has been paid in full, and the stranger’s sacrifice was a demonstration of his love for you. That’s what God did for you 2000 years ago. The Bible says that the God of the Universe became a man (Jesus Christ), and suffered and died on the cross for your sins and mine so that we could be set free. It’s as simple as this-we broke the Law, and Jesus paid our fine. “God demonstrated His own love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.” (Romans 5:8) “Christ redeemed us from the curse of the Law, being made a curse for us.” (Galatians 3:13) Do you see God’s great love for you? Do you see your need for His forgiveness? Do what He commands and “Repent…that your sins may be wiped out and times of refreshing may come from the Lord.” (Acts 3:19) You must turn away from sin and turn to God. Desire to have NOTHING to do with sin, and surrender your life to the One who can save you. Jesus died to set you free, and then he rose from death to be your Lord. Jesus said, “I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life. No one comes to the Father except through me.” If you will confess and forsake your sins (repent) and trust in Jesus Christ as your Savior and Lord, God will forgive you and you’ll pass from death to life. If you are not sure how to pray, read Psalm 51 and make it your prayer. What does it mean to “put your faith in Jesus Christ?” It means to personally trust in Jesus the same way you’d trust in a parachute if you had to jump 25,000 feet out of an airplane. You wouldn’t just “believe” in the parachute; you would put it on! In the same way, the Bible says, “Put on the Lord Jesus Christ…” and you will be saved. There are millions of people who “believe” Jesus exists . . . but they have not put on the Savior-there’s a BIG difference. And the difference will be obvious when you “jump” though the door of death. Today, with all your heart-turn away from sin, and surrender your life to Jesus Christ. Please don’t put it off till later. You may die today and then it will be too late. You may not yet have all the answers to your questions, but better to put on the parachute first and then ask questions, than to pass through the door unprepared, grasping for the parachute when it’s too late. God will transform you from the inside out. You will think and feel differently as you learn to trust and obey Him. God will give you new strength to live right and love Him above all else. Read your Bible daily and obey His Word. You can trust God-He loves you and will always be faithful. If you’ve decided to reject the gift of forgiveness and you die in your sins, there is no hope for you. There is no purgatory. The wrath of God abides on you and you will spend eternity in Hell. Please take the time to read what the Bible says Hell is like.

You may not think deceitfulness is a serious sin, but God does. 10. “You shall not covet.” This means we should never desire anything that belongs to another person. Not their house, nor their car, nor their money, nor their wife, nor their lifestyle, nor anything that belongs to our neighbor Who of us can say we are not guilty of breaking these Commandments? This is what the Bible means when it says, “All have sinned and fall short of the Glory of God.” Can you see your predicament? You are guilty of sinning against God Himself, and, because you have a conscience, (con-with, science-knowledge) you have sinned “with knowledge.” Isn’t it true that every time you lied, stole, or lusted, etc., you knew it was wrong? Does the fact that you have sinned against God scare you? It should.  You have actually angered Him by your sin. The Bible says His wrath abides on you, that you are an “enemy of God in your mind through wicked works.” Perhaps you think God is good and because of his goodness He will overlook your sins? But if you knew of a human judge who turned a blind eye to the crimes of a guilty rapist… would you describe him as “good” judge? God could never be a corrupt judge. He will punish all the rapists, murderers, and thieves… But he won’t stop there. He will also punish all liars, the lustful, adulterers, idolaters, and blasphemers. God does not want you to perish. He is rich in mercy and compassion, and has provided a way for you to be forgiven. He has invited you to come to Him for a full pardon and receive the free gift of Eternal Life. You cannot earn it, and you do not deserve it, but God is offering it to you as proof of His love for you. Imagine you are standing in front of a judge, guilty of multiple serious crimes. All the evidence has been presented and there is no doubt about your guilt. Your apologies and good works cannot erase your crimes; therefore you must be punished. The fine for your crime is $250,000 or imprisonment, but you don’t have two pennies to rub together. The judge is about to pass sentence when someone you don’t even know steps in and pays your fine for you! The court accepts the money and declares that you are free to go. The law has been satisfied, your debt has been paid in full, and the stranger’s sacrifice was a demonstration of his love for you. That’s what God did for you 2000 years ago. The Bible says that the God of the Universe became a man (Jesus Christ), and suffered and died on the cross for your sins and mine so that we could be set free. It’s as simple as this-we broke the Law, and Jesus paid our fine. “God demonstrated His own love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.” (Romans 5:8) “Christ redeemed us from the curse of the Law, being made a curse for us.” (Galatians 3:13) Do you see God’s great love for you? Do you see your need for His forgiveness? Do what He commands and “Repent…that your sins may be wiped out and times of refreshing may come from the Lord.” (Acts 3:19) You must turn away from sin and turn to God. Desire to have NOTHING to do with sin, and surrender your life to the One who can save you. Jesus died to set you free, and then he rose from death to be your Lord. Jesus said, “I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life. No one comes to the Father except through me.” If you will confess and forsake your sins (repent) and trust in Jesus Christ as your Savior and Lord, God will forgive you and you’ll pass from death to life. If you are not sure how to pray, read Psalm 51 and make it your prayer. What does it mean to “put your faith in Jesus Christ?” It means to personally trust in Jesus the same way you’d trust in a parachute if you had to jump 25,000 feet out of an airplane. You wouldn’t just “believe” in the parachute; you would put it on! In the same way, the Bible says, “Put on the Lord Jesus Christ…” and you will be saved. There are millions of people who “believe” Jesus exists . . . but they have not put on the Savior-there’s a BIG difference. And the difference will be obvious when you “jump” though the door of death. Today, with all your heart-turn away from sin, and surrender your life to Jesus Christ. Please don’t put it off till later. You may die today and then it will be too late. You may not yet have all the answers to your questions, but better to put on the parachute first and then ask questions, than to pass through the door unprepared, grasping for the parachute when it’s too late. God will transform you from the inside out. You will think and feel differently as you learn to trust and obey Him. God will give you new strength to live right and love Him above all else. Read your Bible daily and obey His Word. You can trust God-He loves you and will always be faithful. If you’ve decided to reject the gift of forgiveness and you die in your sins, there is no hope for you. There is no purgatory. The wrath of God abides on you and you will spend eternity in Hell. Please take the time to read what the Bible says Hell is like.

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Tim 4:12, “Let no man despise your youth, but be an example to the believers in word, in conduct, in love, in spirit, in faith, in purity”

I find that mentors are vital people in our lives for growth. People we look up to, people who set up standards that serves as a challenge to get us to the next level. We see it in the bible days, Joshua had a mentor Moses whom he looked up to until the torch was passed over to him. We see also with Elijah and Elisha, the bible describes Elisha as the prophet who washed Elijah’s hand. When Elijah called him to follow him, he kissed everything goodbye including the family business he was running to follow Elijah across the country washing his hands and cooking his meals. If that is not enough, we see it again with Naomi and Ruth, we see how Naomi’s life influences Ruth’s that she is inspired to follow her wherever she went. “Your people shall be my people, your God shall be my God, wherever you will die, I will die there too”, she says. Last but not least we also see it with Paul and Timothy.

I don’t know about you but if I did not have some kind of mentor in my life, I would not be where I am spiritually and even ministry wise. Some did not know that they inspired me until much later when I mentioned to them. Why mentor? If you do not have someone around that challenges you spiritually, or in any other areas, it’s easy to loose your edge the reason being that when you don’t see anything more than what you already have you might feel you have attained it all. I remember when I got saved and then five years later lead into the ministry of intercession, my dad was a huge inspiration without him even knowing in the line of prayers, he has always prayed effectively, earnestly and powerfully. When it came to beginning to preach, I was inspired by one youth pastor back then who has since moved to other positions. I told God that if my youth pastor could preach, I could preach too if He anointed me to do so. I have been preaching since then. God used Pastor Phil to challenge me to reach the lost on the streets, been doing it since then (about 8-9years now). I always struggled to do memory verses until I got inspired and rebuked by someone’s life. He did not tell me or encourage me to do it, the way he memorized verses inspired me to ask God for grace and strength to do it. I believe that there are people who come our way we may not be close to but their life style will cause us to want more. I’m not talking about competition or jealousy, I believe God put such people around us to awaken us by reminding us there is more. If God never allowed me  to come across these people may be I would still be stagnant never knowing there is more I can ask God to do in my life for His glory.

My point today is that it’s good to have certain people come our way, we may not know them or even be close to them but something in their lives will give us an appetite to call on God for more. When Moses died, Joshua took over for he had learnt a lot from Moses and so did Elisha from Elijah, Ruth from Naomi and Timothy from Paul. To close, there are people who God will also bring in our lives who are inspired and challenged by us. Let me share with you about one of my best friends. He was once upon a time, a drug addict, sold drugs, was involved in drive by shootings, arrested about 15 times to mention a few. When he got saved, a few weeks later I was introduced to him and we began to hang out, teaching him the things of God, building his faith.  One time he shared with me how he desired to know how to pray effectively and so I invited him to my prayer nights to come listen and be part of it. Being that he was a new believer, I thought my prayer nights would drive him away. But, he came faithfully, listened to me pray every week and not long after, he started praying little by little. Today he is a prayer warrior, the youth pastor at my church, he preaches in jails and soon he will be opening a troubled teen center. I was his best man, my friend is Pastor Paul. Be an example of believers in every place God sets you, you never know who is taking notes and praying that they will be raised like you are. I believe only you can limit what God can do in your life. God will’s by bringing people your way, then waits for you to respond.

Blessings

Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Luke 5:4, “When He had stopped speaking, He said to Simon, “Launch out into the deep and let down your nets for a catch.”

I love good surprises especially from God. I remember when Pastor Phil was getting engaged, he brought now his wife onto a hill if I remember correctly and surprised her there real good.  Tears of joy ran down her cheeks, what a surprise. Wives, remember when your husband proposed? some of you had not clue or if you did, you couldn’t tell when. When He did, you just fell apart, no words to say but shed tears of joy. We all love good surprises for they are things we don’t expect or if we expect them, we do not know when they will drop. Christ will surprise many when He comes back. We know He is coming back again but no one knows the day or the hour. He also confessed that He did not know when but we do see the signs.

Peter was surprised real good at one point in his life. As a professional fisherman, he would go out with other fishermen to fish at night and have fish by morning for the market. One day, they tried fishing all night but caught no fish. In the cold, very dark, maybe windy, exhausting night, all they went through the night was rewarded by the catch in the morning. On this morning, there was no pay for the hard work. There were people waiting for fish in the market, but no fish. Here comes Jesus, un expected by Peter. I’m not sure whether he knew who Jesus was. He may have heard about Him. Jesus comes by the lake with a great multitude. To Peter, these could have been potential customers. On this day, more consumers but no products. Peter and the rest went to wash their nets, maybe thinking of how great it could have been selling fish to the new customers. All they knew to do could not yield any fruit that morning. Someone once said that our God is the God of 11:59, He surprises you when you least expect Him. Over the years, God has surprised me real good and I was left stunned and over joyed.

He might have not known Jesus but I believe Jesus was there to surprise Peter. Yes He taught multitudes but greater miracle was to be recorded when He met Peter. After teaching which is putting the kingdom of God first, He tells Peter, “Launch out into the deep and let down your nets for a catch”,. “Let me tell you something Teacher, we fish at night the time fish is available, already we have tried but nothing happened and by the way, we are professional fishermen while you are a teacher, what would you know about fishing?”, Why try to fish in the hour no one expects to get a catch? That could have been Peter’s thought but listen to his response in vs. 5, “But Simon answered and said to Him, “Master, we have toiled all night and caught nothing; nevertheless at Your word I will let down the net.” I have done the best I could thorough ideas, expertise I mean everything but You are the author of all things, I will cast my faith in that situation again despite what my logic mind tells me. It doesn’t make sense but “I will not lean on my own understanding”, Proverbs 3:5,.

What has failed in the natural, God can accomplish it in the supernatural, we can see this with God showing Jeremiah what He can do with marred clay. Jeremiah 18:4, “…so He made it (marred clay) again into another vessel (means)”. It failed you? it will not fail Him. It got broken? He can fix it, He made ” IT” the same thing, “AGAIN” one more time “ANOTHER”, what you were not expecting. vs. 6, “And when they had done this, they caught a great number of fish, and their net was breaking”. His greatest catch in history, Jesus surprised him real good simply because that was his time. He did not deserve it, he wasn’t looking for it, he didn’t expect it but Jesus knew He needed that surprise cause from that day his life was changed, never to be the same again. Are you opened to surprise the Lord may bring your way? I got one on Friday myself in reaching the lost. Lord surprise us today as you have appointed this day just to be our time.

Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Are you acting impulsively? By Christopher Keck (CK)

content.rendered:
Good morning,

31Then Jesus told them, “This very night you will all fall away on account of me, for it is written:” ‘I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.’32But after I have risen, I will go ahead of you into Galilee.”33Peter replied, “Even if all fall away on account of you, I never will.”34″I tell you the truth,” Jesus answered, “this very night, before the rooster crows, you will disown me three times.”35But Peter declared, “Even if I have to die with you, I will never disown you.” And all the other disciples said the same. (Matt. 26: 31-35).

As defined by freedictionary.com, the word, impulsive means “to act on rather than think”, “motivated or resulting from impulse”. Babylon.com defines impulsive as “rash, hasty; acting on impulse; spontaneous”. I believe that there are three reasons to Peter’s impulsiveness. We first see it in Matthew 16:23, when Jesus was walking with His disciples and told them that He’d have to suffer many things at the hands of the elders of the law. Then, it is written Peter rebuked Jesus. Imagine that? You’re walking with the Lord and you rebuke Him! It may sound crazy, but think about it, because I’m sure I’m not the only one who’s done it before. Peter loved the Lord very much. Have you ever loved someone so much that you put yourself in between them and their future? Peter was very passionate in serving Christ, and guess what? The enemy knew that. The enemy knows you through and through, and even if you were to unconsciously come against the will of God “in love”, it’s still coming against the will of God.

So, the first reason for Peter’s impulsiveness was that, because of his love for the Lord, he acted without thinking, and was used by the enemy to come against what had to be done in order to save souls. The second reason for Peter’s impulsiveness was because he lacked humility and servant leadership. This is evident in Matthew 26:31-35, because without humbling himself and listening to the Lord, he instead spoke selfishly and out of order. Think about it. The last supper just ended, and during its end, Christ’s disciples had a dispute as to who was the greatest among them. Christ had to instruct the twelve that He came to this world as a servant, and so should they live. Imagine, you just come off of a conversation like that, Christ is with you, and warns that the Scriptures fulfillment will be that you’d have to disown Him as Lord. Listen to how Peter speaks in these verses. Don’t forget that the rest of the disciples are with him, and agreed (And all the other disciples said the same; Matt 26:31-35) that they wouldn’t leave Jesus’ side. Peter, through his human nature and passion for Christ, spoke brashly and seemed to win favor amongst the rest of the twelve. If it were me, my flesh would cling on to that saying, “looks like I am the greatest among them”. What are your motives for serving the Lord today?

The final reason for Peter’s impulsiveness was because he lacked experience. How many know that we can walk with the Lord, but that doesn’t mean that He’s equipped us with the trials, and tribulations yet needed to do His will for our lives? Peter denying Jesus three times was the beginning of his burdensome trials that would prepare him to eventually to become the rock that the Lord could use to plant His church upon. Let me tell you. If the Lord intends to use you similarly to the way he used Peter, you’ll be brought down to the pit where the only thing able to stand is your faith. After Peter denied Christ three times, the rooster crowed. And after the rooster crowed, Jesus Christ sifted through the crowd with His eyes, and looked directly at Peter. “The eyes are the windows to the soul”, and Christ saw directly into Peter’s. Imagine the devastation done to Peter’s soul? How that one look from Christ shattered his inner man into tiny pieces, and left him with nothing but faith. It was through this that Peter’s humility was built, his love for Christ was tested and sharpened and his passion to do the Lord’s will was put into realistic terms.

Ask the Lord where you are today. Are you ready? Can your faith sustain you?

Blessings and God be with you

Christopher Keck (CK)

content.rendered:
Good morning,

JN 1:1 In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.   GE 1:1 In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.

Notice, before anything was, God was.  He desires to be “In the beginning” of our lives, our day, our week, our passions.  God First!

EX 20:2 “I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.   EX 20:3 “You shall have no other gods before me.” God desires to be the focal point of your affections God FIRST!

EX 34:1 The LORD said to Moses, “Chisel out two stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on them the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke.” God wanted the LAW to be exactly like the FIRST for Israel to follow, nothing added or deleted.

NU 8:16 They are the Israelites who are to be given wholly to me. I have taken them as my own in place of the firstborn, the first male offspring from every Israelite woman.” The Levites are the substitutes for the firstborn of every mother in Israel. The story line of salvation comes strongly here: Passover!  The angel of death passed over when he saw blood on the posts. The firstborn of Israel were not killed. But for them a price was to be paid, and that price was the Levites. The NT applies Jesus’ blood to our hearts!

Numerous time God desired the first fruits from Israel The “first fruits”–the first sheaf of the harvest offered to the Lord (Lev 23:10-11, 17, 20)–was not only prior to the main harvest but was also an assurance that the rest of the harvest was coming.  Worship First!

1CO 15:20 But Christ has indeed been raised from the dead, the first fruits of those who have fallen asleep. – So with Christ. He was first resurrected to show guarantee of our resurrection at his second coming.

Jas 1:18 He chose to give us birth through the word of truth that we might be a kind of first fruits of all he created.”  The first Christians would multiply through the ages.

33 But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness.  Is He the first that we seek?

MT 8:21-22 Another disciple said to him, “Lord, first let me go and bury my father.” But Jesus told him, “Follow me, and let the dead bury their own dead.” FOLLOW HIM FIRST!

MT 22:37 Jesus replied: ” `Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind.’ 38 This is the first and greatest commandment. LOVE HIM FIRST!

26 “If anyone comes to me and does not hate his father and mother, his wife and children, his brothers and sisters–yes, even his own life–he cannot be my disciple. 27 And anyone who does not carry his cross and follow me cannot be my disciple.  JESUS FIRST!

Mark 13:10 And the gospel must first be preached to all nations.  PREACH HIM FIRST!

Where truly is the Lord on your priority list?  We have jobs, school, family, friends, relationships, hobbies, sports, TV, video games, food, etc…  Be brutally honest. Is God first in your time – how much time does he get? Is He first in your finances – do you give to Him first? Do you use your talents (abilities) to bless Him first?

Blessings,

Pastor Phil <><

title.rendered: The Ineffective Word Of God, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

MK 7:5-13, “These people honor me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me, They worship me in vain; their teachings are but rules taught by men”

There is a personal story of a few years ago with a Catholic priest on tradition verses God’s word.  I wanted to share with him (the priest) how God changed my life (I was an x-Catholic) when I was thirteen years old.   I had introduced myself to “father _______, as Pastor Phil as I had at this time been a licensed minister, trying to relate on a “clergy level.”  Well he didn’t want to hear it, because to him, I had left the Catholic faith, and basically had to get right with God (which meant come back to the Catholic Church).  He didn’t care about my story about God changing me, only about Catholic TRADITION!  After dialoging with him and having him quote tradition verses my quoting of Scripture, things began to heat up.  It became like a ping-pong match literally back and forth, a statement of tradition hit toward me, and a Scripture truth hit toward him.  Holy anger (there is such a thing), for the first time rose up in me, and for a moment in time I felt toward this priest what I can imagine Jesus felt toward the Pharisees.  I asked him to stop referring to me as “son” because he was not my earthly, heavenly, nor a spiritual father to me of any sort.  A father wants to hear their son’s story about God changing their life, not shut it down and shove tradition down their throat.  I asked him a final question in our heated discussion because of my constant quoting of Scripture saying but the Bible doesn’t agree with what you said; because the Bible says this, and I would quote a verse to him.  He said, “you think the Holy Sacred Scriptures contain all the truth, but they don’t, they only contain half the light truth.  The other half is contained by “Holy Sacred Tradition.”  My follow-up question was, “So what happens when your tradition and the Scriptures contradict each other what do you rely on in the end?  His answer was, you always go with sacred tradition. That is when holy anger jumped into my heart, but the Lord gave me this verse from 2 Tim 2:24-26 “And the Lord’s servant must not quarrel; instead, he must be kind to everyone, able to teach, not resentful.25Those who oppose him he must gently instruct, in the hope that God will grant them repentance leading them to a knowledge of the truth,26 and that they will come to their senses and escape from the trap of the devil, who has taken them captive to do his will. ” Needless to say I left there heated, yet experiencing what again I believe to be a similar encounter to what Jesus faced with the Pharisees.

Jesus contrasts the “commands of God” with the “traditions of men” It is clear that this great body of Jewish tradition had failed to get to the heart of God’s commands. Instead of staying within God’s Law, their tradition become a means of getting around God’s law by speaking to them about the seriousness of failure to keep the fifth commandment.  Death is the penalty for anyone who curses his father or mother.  But by means of the tradition, the responsibility of children to their parents could be easily circumvented. A son need only declare that what he had intended to give his father and mother be considered “Corban,” i.e., a gift devoted to God, and it could no longer be designated for his parents. By devoting the gift to God, a son did not necessarily promise it to the temple nor did he prevent its use for himself. What he did do was to exclude legally his parents from benefiting from it. So the very purpose for which the commandment was given was set aside by the tradition. This is what is meant by “nullifying” the word of God or making God’s Word Unproductive, Unsuccessful, Useless, Vain, Fruitless, Futile, Hopeless, and Wasted.  The Word of God is a powerful thing. James 1:22-23 says, “Do not merely listen to the word, and so deceive yourselves. Do what it says.23 Anyone who listens to the word but does not do what it says is like a man who looks at his face in a mirror 24 and, after looking at himself, goes away and immediately forgets what he looks like.” The mirror becomes useless in a persons life who looks into it for it’s intended purpose to give a look at our true selves.  If someone doesn’t comb their hair, change their perhaps un-matching clothes, etc…, then why use the mirror.  It wasn’t the mirrors fault, even if a picture is worth a thousand words.  The same holds true with God’s Law.  It shows who we are in the mirror of truth.  But if we hold onto tradition and forsake God’s word, it’s power working through our lives becomes null and void, which is an offense to a holy God.

1.      Do you regularly read God’s word, if not why not        2.      Understand you show what you believe about God’s word by what you do, not what you say        3.      Is your tradition more important than God’s Word?, be painfully honest        4.       Is God’s Word being effective or ineffective in your life, if so how.        5.      If you need to repent do so quickly, don’t put it off. If things are great thank God and continue to let God prune you and abide in the vine (John 15),

Blessings

title.rendered: The Ineffective Word Of God, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,

MK 7:5-13, “These people honor me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me, They worship me in vain; their teachings are but rules taught by men”

I would like to bring you the devotion this morning titled the Ineffective Word of God.  According to a thesaurus the word Ineffective can also be defined as the following:  Unproductive, Unsuccessful, Useless, Vain, Fruitless, Futile, Hopeless, and Wasted.  What, none of those definitions would fit the power of the Word of God.   As a matter of fact they are the opposite of what the Bible says about it self as in Hebrews 4:12, “For the word of God is Quick and powerful (living and active). Sharper than any double-edged sword….”  Or perhaps 2 Tim 3:16, “All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness.”

PROBLEM. Is the word of God Quick, Alive, Powerful, Sharper than any Two-Edged Sword, God breathed and able to be used for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness?  Or is it Ineffective?  It can’t be both, or can it?  Let’s examine our passage in Mark 7. The Pharisees came to Jesus and they discovered that Jesus’ disciples did not wash their hands before eating (v. 2Tohoroth Jewish custom of ceremonial hand washing, a custom based on the “tradition of the elders” (v. 35-756hypokrites7). Their complaint was not, of course, that the disciples by this failure were being unhygienic. The Pharisees had no concern with that. The question was one of ceremonial purity versus ceremonial defilement. We know that the Jews placed great importance on this as is shown by the fact that an entire division of the Mishnah (“cleanness’s”) is devoted to this subject.  This consisted in a great mass of oral tradition that had arisen about the law. About A.D. 200 it was written down in the Mishnah, but in Jesus day it was still in oral form. It’s purpose was to regulate a man’s life completely. If the law was silent or vague about a particular subject, one could be sure that the tradition would be vocal and explicit. The tradition, created and promulgated by the great rabbis, was passed on from one generation to the next and was considered binding. To the question asked Jesus as to why His disciples acted as they did, He answered by quoting a passage from Isaiah, preceded by his own comment: “Isaiah was right when he prophesied about you hypocrites” meaning “play actor” and refers here to people whose worship is merely outward and not from the heart. Rather they carried out all their traditions and regulations and were heartless hypocrites. Their outward appearance of piety was a lie, because it was not accompanied by a “total life commitment to the one who is the true object of religious devotion” (Anderson, p. 185). Jesus goes on (v. ) to equate neglect of true holiness to submission to man-made rabbinic tradition.

To continue,

Blessings

Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 26:36-46, vs. 41, “Watch and pray, lest you enter into temptation. The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.”

Prayer is vital and most necessary yet it’s one of the hardest things to do. I know not of anyone who finds it easy to pray, being in the presence of God, lingering longer speaking to our heavenly Father. While it’s vital, I also think it’s one of the most neglected, or casually treated. Some may not even see a great need for it. David Wilkerson called our generation “A praising people but not a praying people”.

In our text we see the struggle with prayer with Jesus’ very close inner circle friends. The time when they needed to pray the most; the most crucial time, they fell a sleep. Jesus in the earlier verses had spoken of His betrayal and even mentioned to His disciples of the challenges before them. He provided information they needed, hopefully that would drive them to pray. And here we find Jesus calling for a prayer meeting, bringing in His closest friends to pray with Him and what happened? they fell asleep at an hour of prayer.

Jesus being Man (flesh and blood) depended on the Father through prayer. He prayed for His disciples, He even told Peter at one point that He had prayed for him when the devil desired to sift him as wheat. Prayer was crucial in Jesus’ life in good times and in hard times. How much more do we need to do it ourselves?

41, “Watch and pray, lest you enter into temptation. The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.”, while we struggle, by what other means is there to gain victory but by prayer. Only devotion to prayer can carry us through the hardest times. Our best intentions cannot protect us in the time of severest testing unless we have learned how to seek God in prayer. The disciples had good intentions “The spirit indeed was willing”, the flesh was weak and of course the flesh does not want the idea of prayer. I find that when we struggle the most, that is when we need to pray the most. And that is the time to crucify the flesh and bring it under the obedience of Christ. If the devil can succeed to make us fall asleep, he would have succeeded in disarming us of the means we have to reach the Father.

Jesus had already warned His disciples to pray lest they succumb to the test, a warning applicable to all disciples; his admonitions to watch likewise apply to all disciples in all eras. I find it interesting that Jesus did not say I will pray for you, He said “you watch (be awake) and you pray which is a clear indication that it’s not left for certain people. If you are a true follower of Christ, then prayer ought to be vital part of your life.

What is prayer to you, is it a duty or a privilege? Is it a must do or is it a delight? Is it an occasional or a daily communion? We live at a time that we as Jesus disciples need to heed the same call, “watch and pray”, lest we enter into temptation of pride, apathy, lukewarmeness, hard times a head etc,

Blessings Ev.

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Samuel 17:1-58, “Then he took his staff in his hand; and chose for himself five smooth stones from the brook…”

1Samuel 17:32, “Then David said to Saul, “Let no man’s heart fail because of him; your servant will go and fight with the Philistine”, Here is a mind made up to please the Father, everyone including the king did not feel David was ready for he was young, inexperienced, not trained on war but God readied him for this battle. vs. 38, “So Saul clothed David with his armor…”, you can’t fight in someone else’s armor, BE YOURSELF, use what you know works for you because you have tested and proven it. Saul thought that since Goliath was equipped and ready, trying to dress David would do the same. All David needed was his point of reference (what God had done in his life) and what God was going to do if he remained himself in the Lord. David could not fight with what he had not proven neither can we.

1Samuel 17:40, “Then he took his staff in his hand; and chose for himself five smooth stones from the brook…”. This is the core message. David took his staff not anybody’s and went to the brook and picked out five smooth stones. This to me has a great significance, the stones represent good skills to win a battle. He picked them from a brook. The bible says, “you shall be like a tree planted by the waters, Elijah was brought to a brook, The bible says, “Jesus is the living water”, “out of your belly shall flow rivers of life”. This shows that David was picking what he needed from God. Mark this, the stones were smooth and polished not just any stone. Have you and I picked the smooth stones from the brook of God to overcome? Talents, abilities, strengths to mention a few. On your job resume, you talk about your abilities and strength,. the employers tend to look at some of these because they become an advantage to what they are looking for. If you have smooth stones of meeting deadlines, honest, dependable, and adaptable and the like, this would add to your qualifications. You have to pick out your smooth stones to get you anywhere. What are your smooth stones? David picked his from the brook. Where do you get yours from?

1Samuel 17:45, “…You come to me with a sword, with a spear, and with a javelin. But I come to you in the name of the Lord of hosts, …”, many believe that the stone brought Goliath down, I doubt it, I believe what David spoke to the giant melted his heart when he showed God strong on his behalf. All Goliath now saw was not David but God in David, the stone merely finished the job. Your smooth stone will only finish the job started by involving God in your affairs. Your confession that you are able through God’s help will help you begin the work of overcoming, your abilities and strengths accomplishes what was began. We pray give us a chance as long as we know we can truly depend on God to see us through. David might not have had what was required for the battle in the natural sense but in the spiritual sense he did. Give us a chance and we will show Him So strong before men.

Blessings

Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Samuel 17:1-58, “Then he took his staff in his hand; and chose for himself five smooth stones from the brook…”

The bible is interesting in the sense that it could take time and dwell on something, fully describing it e.g. 1Samuel 17:4, “And a champion went out from the camp of the Philistines, named Goliath from Gath, whose height was six cubits and spans” Read it until vs. 7, the 4 verses talks about nothing but how the giant was dressed for battle. The bible wants us to see something about this man. Just reading how equipped he was, I could see why the Israelites were afraid of him. This was no ordinary sizable man. I wondered why the bible wouldn’t just say he was a giant and a champion. I believe the Lord wants us to know that our enemy is not a wimp as many may think. He is prepared for you and me. Goliath was more qualified, trained, prepared, ready, equipped, eloquent, developed, sophisticated, protected, confident, threatening and a fighter, what chance did David have? All the trained men, who have all that it takes to battle, could not face the giant. Ever wondered why the bible does not even take time to describe how Saul was dressed for the battle? The Lord would have us know that no matter how big, strong and well prepared the enemy might be, our stand is in 1John 4:4, “ye are of God, little children for you have overcome them: because for greater is He that is in you, that he that is in the world”. You might be looking at the position God allowed you to have and looking at its requirements you get scared silly as whether you can handle the job. If you know who you are in Christ and Christ brings you to see what you did not even ask for, that is a sign that He will qualify you to overcome it. I have seen this work in my life, God brought me to something that I wasn’t even qualified for as the description showed me how Goliath was dressed but “God is not a respecter of persons, He is a respecter of principles”. If God brought you to this point, believe that He will take you to that point, Philippians 1:6, “Being confident of this very thing, that He which has began a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ”

This is the concept David learnt when the rest could not and with that in mind he set himself to fight the giant and the first obstacle was his brothers. 1Samuel 17:28, “Now Eliab his older brother heard when he spoke to the men; and Eliab’s anger was aroused against David..” Sounds familiar?, not everyone is ready for your progress, some say, “there is no way you can make it”, “there is no way you can have that position”, “there is no way you can change that department”, “you have nothing it takes to make a change, look at us who are more qualified and should do it but we are not because we are unable”. To make the matters worse, the brother accused him of coming to watch the war, accused him of pride, and was reminded of where he belonged in the wilderness with the sheep. What would you do if you  believed God to make it then you have someone in the church, in the home, or a friend discourage you? They speak death over your situation, “There is no way you can make it?”. David would have said, “Well you are right, I will pack up my stuff and go home”. This was not his attitude, if he went back home, that would mean he couldn’t trust God enough. Already he knows that he did not come to the battle ground to watch yet he has been accused of it, he begins to see that God set him up because he wasn’t looking for this job. He just knows that he has a chance to show how God is so strong among His people.

Ask yourself this question, maybe you were not looking to be somewhere but God graciously brought you to that place, you know of your limitations, you have things and people trying to discourage you from doing what is right, something that will bring honor to His name. You have a chance to make a difference, you know who is in you, what will you do about it? Is your desire to have a chance?

To continue,

Blessings

Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Samuel 17:1-58, “Then he took his staff in his hand; and chose for himself give smooth stones from the brook…”

I’ve come across people with hidden potentials yet to be discovered. In the entertainment world people are being discovered because of their talents. I’ve heard of people sharing about their humble beginning and often times you hear about a struggles involving rejections, written off words spoken that they were not good enough but later they broke through.

Everyone desires a chance to show what they have within, their talents, abilities, skills, performance, or products. A chance to be a boss, husband, wife, teacher, worker etc. People will always cry, “give me a chance to show what I can do”. We also see this in the work force, people who see new positions that they may not have all the qualifications needed but they believe in themselves that given a chance, they can do it. A belief that you can offer something and make a difference can push you to desire a chance. Our chance as believers is not to show off, but make God look big in the eyes of men. He is already big let’s not forget that, but for the people in the world, we need to show them how Big Our God is. 2Chronicles 16:9, “For the eyes of the Lord run to and fro throughout the whole earth, to show Himself so strong on behalf of those whose hearts are loyal to Him”. He has given us a chance to show Him so strong.

There is a big difference between knowing what to do…and doing what you know. Most people know what to do but they cannot propel and believe in God in them to do what they could not do themselves. They have potentials hidden.  David and Goliath is a story that reveals some things that are vital in our lives. We know David’s position, he is a shepherd boy, taking care of sheep and smells like one. Though young, he is good at what he does, he is faithful in his job. An opportunity rises when his father sends him to the battleground to bring food to his brothers. Again we see that he is also obedient he does what he’s been asked to do. I’m not sure whether he loved to take care of the sheep when his brothers were soldiers in the army but I do know that he knew his job pretty well. He was faithful and obedient in doing so. You may not like what you do, but can you still be good at it, faithful and obedient while trusting God to elevate you in due time? I believe God sees our attitude in what we do and if we cannot be content first with where we are, we will not be content when we move because before long…you know the rest. Anyway, David has a chance to be all he can be while still attending to the sheep.

1Samuel 17:20, “So David rose in early in the morning… and took the things and went as Jesse (his father) had commanded him”, I say boldly that God was setting this young man up. He does not know what awaits him, maybe he never saw himself beyond being a shepherd boy but his obedience leads him to serve his superiors (his brothers) without murmuring and complaining. Now David coming to the grounds finds that the enemies are not fighting each other, he has just left what he brought with the supply keeper, runs to the battle ground to greet his brothers and in the process of time, he hears about Goliath sending threats to the Israelites. David has just learnt that no one including the king has the capability of facing this giant. They rehearse to him what will happen to any man who can kill Goliath. It’s like hearing, a job description and the benefits. The job is to kill Goliath, benefits are great riches, a hand of king’s daughter in marriage and exemption from taxes. What an opportunity but who is he? what chance does he have?.

We’ll tackle more on it tomorrow. Have a blessed morning,

Evans

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1 Samuel 1:11 “O Lord of hosts, if thou wilt indeed look on the affliction of thine handmaid, and remember me, and not forget think handmaid, but wilt give unto think handmaid a man child, then I will give him unto the Lord all the days of his life, and there shall no razor come upon his head.”

WOW, what a whooper of a desperate prayer.  Hannah in one chapter shares her deepest heart chamber with God, because it seemed that only He would understand.  She was a woman who was misunderstood by those around her.  The Lord had closed her womb which in OT times was viewed as a curse by God.  She was provoked severely by Peninnah, Elkanah’s other wife, for it and her heart was deeply grieved.  She would only weep and not even eat, and bitterness of soul built up within her.  Not even her own husband nor Eli the priest (the spiritual one) understood her sorrowful spirit.  So what did she do?  Did she set out to kill her husband or the other wife, because she couldn’t conceive a child?  Did she verbally try to abuse the other wife or try and defend her situation?  Did she verbally attack Eli the priest for not being able at first to understand her condition, for even he thought her to be drunk as she prayed her prayer?  No, she did none of these things that were possible reactions by any other in her situation.  What would you have done?

How did Hannah finally respond to her sorrowful situation, of no one understanding her, and being labeled as cursed by God Himself?  She prayed a prayer.  She didn’t take up arms and go postal, run away, or even take her own life?  No, she prayed a powerful, real, heartfelt, from the guts of her desperation, prayer.

Just then, the Lord remembered (not that He ever forgot) her, answering her prayer.  And granted her a son, the prophet Samuel.  God answered her prayer, bigger and greater than she could have ever imagined.  But isn’t God like that, we ask for something in His will, and He goes above and beyond what we had seen through our many times lack of faith.

She responded to God in a way that we need to when God blesses us, in worship and thanksgiving, lest we worship the blessing, and not the Blesser!  “For this child I have prayed; and the Lord hath given me my petition which I asked of Him:  Therefore also I have lent him to the Lord; as long as he liveth he shall be lent to the Lord. And he worshiped the Lord there.”   *This child – Samuel

*I have prayed – she labored in prayer

*The Lord hath given me – she acknowledges that God alone blessed her

*I have lent him to the Lord – she, and no one else, gave him back to God unconditionally in dedication to the Lord’s work.  She was a mom of faith.  She didn’t give up something for lent (40 days give it to God then take it back), she gave completely open handed to God.   Ø What about you, are you in a desperate situation, then pray, He hears as He remembered Hannah, He will remember you.

Ø When God blesses you, in His way, will you give back to Him open handed?

Ø Self check – The USA chokes on the blessings of God greatly.  Is there anything God gave you that you are worshiping, instead of giving back to Him?  One must be painfully honest to break free from any idolatry.

Ø Remember – God loves us to give back to Him what He has given up, but He most desires us to lend Him a life, our life, and lead others to Him that they might lend their lives to the Lord as well.

Blessings

Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Gen 39:1-15, “…But he left his garment in her hand, and fled and ran outside”

No one plans to be tempted though some people carry temptations with them so that if they get tempted, they have an excuse to fall. We also find ourselves in situations where we were not looking for trouble but trouble found us. Joseph did not plan to be tempted or put himself in a situation that would allow him to. But when the situation presented itself, he flee. What about us?, flee youthful lust, turn the TV off if it causes you to stumble, get rid of your computer if it makes you fall; go home, it’s one of the best ways to stay out of trouble. Don’t allow yourself to be left alone in certain hours of day or  night with the opposite sex who is not your spouse, it’s not safe or wise. 1Cor 7:1&2, “Now concerning the things that you wrote unto me: it’s good for a man not to touch a woman, nevertheless, to avoid fornication, let every man have his own wife, and let every woman have her own husband”.

Also 1Cor 10:23, says “All things are lawful, but not all things are profitable. All things are lawful, but not all things edify” and this goes for even dressing for most of them are lawful but they are not profitable, they don’t add anything to ones life but causes another to stumble, they don’t edify. How many times have we heard men come to church with pure hearts to pray and be ministered to and then a lady walks through the door dressed in away causing the person who came in to have communion with God to lust after her. Why cause many men to sin because of what you perceive to be okay for you? We have to be wise for one day we will be judged for our actions. How I pray that we will check how we dress, to work, to church, around people and the like for what is okay for us could be a stumbling block for someone else.

Romans 12:2, “And be not conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, that you may prove what is that good and acceptable and perfect will of God”, we can’t live and do things the world’s way for they are lost but we have to do it God’s way for we are found. It begins with our minds transformed to think, discern, act and be wise. Everyday our minds ought to be renewed for the thoughts that come in them many times are not clean thoughts. We also need to prove what is good, not what we think is good but what we know to be good and acceptable not by me but by God, my authorities, the people around me and let it be according to the will of God. I did not come this far to fall. I have given up so much, stayed away from many things to protect the anointing in me, the calling, the zeal and the fire of God. If any of these leaves me, there will be nothing left in me and that is why David in Psalm 51 says, “Take not thy Holy Sprit from me, but restore unto me the joy of thy salvation and renew a right Spirit within me”. What you have worked hard for many years can go in days. When you know that you have come to far to go back, you will continue act like Joseph, RUN, FLEE. CHANGE YOUR WAYS AND BE WHAT GOD WANTS YOU TO BE, A VESSEL OF HONOR.

Blessings

Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Gen 39:1-15, “…But he left his garment in her hand, and fled and ran outside”

Temptation is not bad until it’s allowed to mature up and lead someone into sin. The bible says that Jesus was tempted in all manner but without sin. Someone said, “Lead me not into temptation because I can find it myself” and so it’s easy to sin and very hard to stay pure.

Gen 39:6&7 “… Now Joseph was handsome and good looking and after time his master’s wife cast her eyes upon Joseph and said lie with me”. The eyes act like a video camera, the mind becomes the tape that records everything the eyes see, the body is the audience ready to practice what it has watched in the mind. Everything starts from somewhere and it progresses, therefore as children of God we have to be very careful about what we watch, where we go, the people we hang out with especially of the opposite sex and not be in compromising positions and situations. One preacher said that when it comes to sexual temptations, the mind goes to sleep first without you knowing just like you can’t catch yourself falling a sleep, you will only see the results. The bible says that Portiphar’s wife day after day pressed and persuaded Joseph to go to bed with her but he refused and stayed strong. I can’t say that just because He stayed strong he wasn’t tempted to act on it. Staying strong is not enough, hang around the same stuff for a while it will begin to pull you down. Going down does not happen instantly; it begins little by little and progresses from one stage to another until it gets out of control. It has a way of trying to persuade you and entices you slowly by slowly until you give in. On this particular day after several attempts, she tries to force herself on Joseph and he tries to explain why he shouldn’t do it and the best thing he could do was run away. 2Tim 2:22, “Flee youthful lusts: but follow righteousness, faith, charity, peace, with them that call on the Lord out of pure heart”, Paul when writing, he does not say sit there and cast out the demons or explain yourself as to why it is wrong, or even try to be strong, he is telling us to run. If you can’t beat the devil in his game, you need to be wise and change location, what you are dealing with is more powerful than you think. Those who have fallen at one point believed that they could handle it but you later hear that things got out of control. Though running away and being lied about caused Joseph his job, he maintained his integrity for God was on the verge of lifting him up. One little thing almost caused him his dream for he nearly stumbled, he chose to be a vessel of honor Psalm 73:2, “But as for me, my feet had almost stumbled; my steps had nearly slipped” to finish. Blessings Ev

Good morning,

Mathew 6:9, “…Our Father in heaven, HALLOWED BE YOUR NAME

While it’s easy to come to prayers with our “give me list”, Jesus taught his disciples to first hallow God’s name. He is our Abba Father, Jehovah Yahweh, Jehovah Jireh, Jehovah Shammah, Jehovah Shalom, Jehovah Nissi, Jehovah Elshadai, Jehovah Adonai, Jehovah Tsidekanu, Jehovah Ebenezer, Jehovah Rapha, Jehovah Mkadesh, Jehovah Rohi, King of kings, Lord of lords, Bright morning star, Lion of the tribe of Judah, Prince of Peace, Everlasting Father, Maker of the universe, Jesus Christ, Lily of the valley, Rose of Sharon, Emmanuel, Messiah, Majesty, the I Am, the Porter, The Excellent One, The Mighty One of Israel, Powerful God, Mighty God, Glorious One, Holy God, Magnificent God, Deliverer, Precious Lord, Beautiful Savior, Alpha and Omega, Beginning and the End, First and the Last, Mighty Warrior, Exalted One, Auspicious God who sits on the circles of the earth, Unchanging God, The Lord who reigns forevermore, our Councilor, Living Word, Living Water, Living Bread, the Way, the Truth, the Life, The light of the world, Rock of ages, Solid Rock, Anchor of life, Firm Foundation, Rock of Salvation, Awesome God, Lover of our soul, Consuming Fire, Anointed One, True Vine, our Refuge, our Fortress, A strong Tower, the Lamb that takes away the sins of men, Baptizer of the Holy Ghost and Fire, Jealous God, Sovereign God, Lord of all, Good Shepherd, Teacher, Rabbi, the only Wise God, the all knowing God, the chief planner, Way Maker, Ancient of Days, Master, Redeemer, Rabboni, Omniscient, the balm of Gilead, God of wonders, God of Justice, Merciful God and the list continues.

What a way to show that He is concerned about our affairs as His sons and daughters. People will fail us, but our Father in heaven will never leave us nor forsake us. He is the friend who sticks closer than a brother. As I talk about Him, I am reminded that He is everything good I could ever think about.

Mathew 6:9, “…Hallowed be Your name” His name is sacred, holy, consecrated, blessed, and sanctified. What a name!!!! no one has and no one will ever have such an introduction like God because no one disserves it like He does. Know God as He is for He is the One and only, let your faith increase as you see God as God. Blessings Ev Check out “That’s my King”, http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yzqTFNfeDnE&feature=related
