content.rendered:
Good morning,

2Timothy 3:16, “All Scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness, 17, that the man of God may be complete, thoroughly equipped for every good work”

Several objections to the word of God have been raised and the common one is, “wasn’t the bible written by men?” if so, it would be based on men’s beliefs and opinions. How about if the word of God is true, then why are there so many versions? I would submit to us that God works among men through men. There are certain things He has chosen not to accomplish without involving man. This is not an indication that He is unable to make it happen but His choice is to involve men in what He does. To think about it, God could have saved the entire world without allowing Jesus to be a man on the face of the earth to go through the suffering before saving the world. This makes me believe that you cannot redeem what you are not related to. Had the bible been dropped from heaven, we would find it hard to relate to it, thank God for writing it through men.

Why use man anyway? For us to understand that God speaks to men and through men. That there is such a connection between the Creator and His creation. This is part of the relationship that He has with mankind. Look at Genesis 2:19, “Now the LORD God had formed out of the ground all the beasts of the field and all the birds of the air. He brought them to the man to see what he would name them; and whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name”. God created then used a man to name His creation. Part of being able to use man to accomplish His plans also gives us a testimony of what He is capable of doing for they become our point of reference. Moses was there when the red sea parted, him giving us that account of what happened helps us understand what God can do.

2Timothy 3:16, “All Scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness, “In as much as we know that the Scriptures were written by men, we understand that God breathed or inspired man to do the writing through His guidance. One of the reasons for this I believe was to show men that they were created for a purpose. Men have significance, value and a purpose, that is how God intended men to be. All these are fulfilled through God breathed word. The bible is “profitable for doctrine”, don’t we all learn by either teaching or observing, how will you know your significance, value and purpose without being taught?. You know what you know because you were taught directly or indirectly. I know who I am in Christ because the word of God has taught me. The word of God is for reproof and correction, what away to allow the word to keep us in check and in line. Why do we have a lot of problems in our societies? People have forgotten the book that keeps them in line. Not too long ago on TV, several young people were asked to name the Ten Commandments, 90% would not even name one. A different question followed and they all got them right and that was, “name all the beer brands you know”. They did not even struggle with that one; they spilled them like they were rapping. It seams no one ever taught them, they lived as they saw fit and what the society presented to them. The Bible is also for instruction, a map to the treasure Joshua 1:8, “This Book of the Law shall not depart from your mouth, but you shall meditate in it day and night, that you may observe to do according to all that is written in it. For then you will make your way prosperous, and then you will have good success”.

Vs 17that the man of God may be complete, thoroughly equipped for every good work”, If we can be taught, reproved, corrected and instructed through His word, then vs. 17 comes in , “a man of God may be complete” not perfect, equipped for every good work. Luke 6:45, “A good man out of the good treasure (God’s word) of his heart brings forth good…for out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks. The bible is no ordinary book, it’s a living book written by God through men, the best selling book, by the greatest author, translated in hundreds of languages. Value His word, Desire it, Live according to His word.

Blessings

Ev

content.rendered:
Luke 14:28- “Which of you, intending to build a tower, does not sit down first and count the cost, whether he has enough to finish it.” In verses 25-33 of Luke 14, our Lord says a few very challenging things to us, but verse 28 seems to be a good starting point for each as they continue on their Christian journey. We each must be sure to count the cost, lest we be unwilling in the end to pay what is due.

To often today, Christianity is portrayed as something it is not, and folks never count the cost, they set out on this path and quite soon they take another one that is easier and more pleasant, but one full of compromise and lies, which leads not to holiness and life eternal, but to worldliness and death. Faith is ongoing, it never ends, it does not consist of saying a prayer once, but it is lived out everyday in obedience to His word. Saying a prayer once does not save you, but continued obedience and faith in Christ will see you through to the end. Jesus says unless we forsake ALL, we cannot be His disciple. Whoever does not bear his cross cannot be His disciple. Whoever does not go on to perfection(Hebrews 6:1), walking by faith and obedience will not enter into His rest.

The grace of God is what enables us to live this life in holiness unto the Lord. His grace is continually working in us, forming within each the newness of life found in Christ, it is not a covering for sin, nor is it a free ticket to Heaven, for only He who endures to the end shall be saved. True holiness and righteousness is imparted within us, causing an inner transformation, the change of our very nature.

The cost of discipleship is simple, it is everything. This is true Christianity. It is not a self help course, nor a get rich quick scheme. God would rather you be dirt poor than go to hell, the eternal soul is His concern. Christianity requires self denial, and the forsaking of all. Only when we truly abandon ourselves will we begin to bear the likeness of Christ, as He transforms us inwardly. So many today, “grew up in the church,” but they never truly made a decision for Christ, they never counted the cost, they never forsook all to be His disciple, they simply tried to inherit what must be birthed within each one by faith. Beloved, our Lord has made abundant provision for each one, He died to consecrate for us a “new and living way”(Heb. 10:20), that we might enter into a life with Him that grows deeper each day, a life of fulfillment that surpasses all this world has to offer, is it worth the cost to you? Forsaking all to be His disciple, Brother Ben

title.rendered: Fear The Lord Of Host, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Sanctify the Lord of Host Himself: and let Him be your fear, and let Him be your dread.  (Isa. 8:13)

Sanctify the Lord of Hosts of Hosts Himself: To sanctify is to set apart.  How can someone set God apart?  Is He not already set apart, doesn’t He set Himself apart?  But here in this verse the context is focused on the criticism between Isaiah and his disciples.  Why, because anytime one speaks the truth for the Lord, the critics will be quick to rise up.  And many times it seems as if the critics are the majority against you and the other bold Christians who are speaking the truth about the reality of God.  When I was in my public high school, I had a Bible club there that was kicked out on the grounds of “separation of church and state.”  The critics were students, some teachers and the superintendent.  Here’s where the decision lay, do I fear the superintendent, students, and teachers, or fight for the Lord fearing His call to evangelize my school which the majority are going to hell? I choose to fear the Lord, and fight.  After 3 months it was back in school.  Why?, because we will always serve what we fear.  If you fear man, you will serve him; if you fear God you will serve Him; and the opposite is true also in not serving what you don’t fear.  You ever wonder why only 2% of Christians reach the lost?, It’s because of FEAR. FEAR stands for:  False Evidence Appearing Real.
Let Him be your fear: Everyone fears something; why not fear something worth fearing, namely the Lord of lords.  He is the highest position of authority in every land and in every nation.  Most don’t stand up for God because again they fear man.  Who are you fearing more than God?  We don’t live in the fear of the Lord sometimes, but always.  “Let Him”…shows a submissive spirit, verses a prideful one.  Fire could burn you, but God is a consuming fire; man can kill you, but the Lord is a warrior;, and a tidal wave can overtake you, but my God is a Tsunami (Japanese Major Tidal Wave) of unmatched power.
Let Him be your dread: The NT puts it this way:  Do not be afraid of those who kill the body but cannot kill the soul. Rather, be afraid of the One who can destroy both soul and body in hell.  (Mt. 10:28).
Though man may have power, the worst thing man can do can never match the worst thing God can do.  God has the power to send the disobedient, unregenerate, unsaved to Hell.   And although Satan too may be powerful, only God can destroy both body and soul in Hell.  That is why “The Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom…”
Ask yourself (Reflect honestly)
1.      Is there anyone:  boss, spouse, brother/sister, co-worker, friend, authority figure, that I fear more than God?

2.      Do I abide in the fear of the Lord daily and consistently in what I choose to watch, listen to, read, say, think about, and how I work.  Do I share the Gospel with the lost so they won’t end up in hell like the (2%) or am I like the 98% of Christians who walk past the sinner like the Levite priest verses the Good Samaritan?

Blessings

Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

The word “holiness” carries with it some unwanted baggage, thanks to “religion.” In the East, to be a holy man means to sit naked with your legs crossed, and having folks give you money in return for your blessing. Some holy men sit on poles for twenty years (Pillar Saints). Others stay off poles but they stay away from any contact with a sinful world, in a holier-than-thou legalism. Others live in monasteries, and have a vow of silence. Much of the Church doesn’t live on poles or have a holier than thou attitude. They do however live in a monastery – one without walls. They, too, have a vow of silence. Few have physical contact with the world. Their association with humanity is strictly confined to the Church. Fellowship is what they have on Wednesday nights, Sunday mornings and Sunday nights. The are salt among salt, light among light.

True holiness is the opposite of the above. It does mean that we cut ourselves off from the sin, but not from the sinners. True holiness is to be like Jesus – “separate from sin” and yet He was accused of being a “friend of sinners.” The Scriptures admonish us with these thought-provoking words: “I wrote to you in an epistle not to company with fornicators: Yet not altogether with the fornicators of this world, or with the covetous, or extortioners, or with idolaters; for then must you needs go out of the world. But now I have written to you not to keep company, if any man that is called a brother be a fornicator, or covetous, or an idolater, or a railer, or a drunkard, or an extortioner; with such an one no not to eat” (1Corinthians 5:9-10). Can you see what the Bible is saying? If we separate ourselves from sinners, we won’t be able to reach them with the gospel of salvation. The only ones we are told to separate ourselves from are hypocrites. Look at these wonderful words from George MacLeod of Scotland: “I simply argue that the cross should be raised at the center of the marketplace as well as on the steeple of the church. I am recovering the claim that Jesus was not crucified in a cathedral between two candles, but on a cross between two thieves; on the town’s garbage heap; at a crossroad, so cosmopolitan they had to write His title in Hebrew and Latin and Greek . . . at the kind of a place where cynics talk smut, and thieves curse, and soldiers gamble. Because that is where He died. And that is what He died for. And that is what He died about. That is where church-men ought to be and what church-men ought to be about.”

There is nothing “spiritual” about being holy. It just means a separation from sin. God is holy – He is sinless, and we too are called to be holy: “But as He who has called you is holy, so you be holy in all manner of conversation” (1 Peter 1:15) See Isaiah 6:3; Revelation 15:4. See also Romans 6:19, 22; Ephesians 1:4; Titus 1:8; 1 Peter 1:15.

It’s as simple as this – God has given us an umbrella in the Savior to shelter us from the reign of His wrath. God has given the covering, and we are told to stay under that covering of holiness. How may we best do that? We do this by reading God’s Word daily and by the cultivation of a tender conscience. By having an obedient heart, and by living in the fear of God.

The next time you try to witness to someone you know isn’t right with God, and he suddenly says, “Oh, I’ve been born again. I know the Lord,” ask him if he is “living in holiness.” More than likely he will say that he is. Then call his bluff. Ask him to define “holiness.” As he is straining his brain to come up with a definition, say, The Bible says, “Without holiness, no man shall see the Lord” This means that we should be separated from sin and the world and then ask him if he thinks he’s a good person. More than likely he will, so take the time to take him through the Moral Law.

Blessings

Pastor Phil.

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies…”Psalm 23:5

David wrote Psalm 23 toward the end of his life, and therefore it is his reflection of God worked in the life of David.  David had the following experiences: tending sheep, defeating Goliath, being chased by King Saul, being anointed King of Israel, committing adultery, repenting of his sin, etc….  To say that David had a full life of vast experiences would be an understatement.  Many of us are familiar with this most popular Psalm but what snapshot of David’s life was he thinking of when he wrote, “You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies…?”  Was Goliath on his mind, or one of his many battles that he led?  I believe that David reflected on the time his sheep were hunted by a lion or a bear that could easily devour and carry it away. However David was the sheep, and he wasn’t being hunted by a foreign army, or even any such enemy of Israel, he was being hunted by an enemy lion, with the attributes of Satan who seeks to steal kill and destroy, that was supposed to be on his side.

“He came to the sheep pens along the way; a cave was there, and Saul went in to relieve himself. David and his men were far back in the cave. The men said, “This is the day the LORD spoke of when he said to you, ‘I will give your enemy into your hands for you to deal with as you wish.’ ” Then David crept up unnoticed and cut off a corner of Saul’s robe (1 Sam. 24:3-4).”

Perhaps the worst enemies of all are those that you think are on your side, but that pursue your demise.  There may be any number of reasons such as jealousy or bitterness, which in the case with David and Saul seemed to be the prevalent reasons.  David learned how to dodge Saul’s spears time and time again, and now David is hiding out far back in a cave.  Interestingly enough though while David and his men were at the back of the cave, guess who laid down to rest near the front of cave? Saul!  God had prepared a table for David in the presence of his enemy Saul.  David had Saul in the palm of his hand as David was standing over a sleeping Saul he raised his blade over Saul. WOW, God had given David’s enemy into his hands for him to deal with as he wished.  David being more honorable man than Saul chooses to spare Saul’s life by bringing the blade down and cutting off a piece of Saul’s robe to show that he could have taken Saul’s life.

“…The eyes of the LORD are on the righteous and his ears are attentive to their cry;” God’s favor rested with a righteous David as he brought his enemy to him and placed David’s enemy in a vulnerable state.  God has a way of bringing down our enemies, and preparing a table of blessing before us in their presence.  David could have killed Saul, but he didn’t.  David implored what we now read as Christ’s words, “Bless your enemies.”  Are their perhaps those that are seeking your demise because God is looking with favor upon you?  Do not fear because God has a way of bringing your enemies to your feet and preparing a table before you in the very presence of your enemies.

Application:  Have you been following the world’s advice of “don’t get mad, get even?”  “Do not take revenge, my friends, but leave room for God’s wrath, for it is written: “It is mine to avenge; I will repay,” says the Lord. On the contrary: “If your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him something to drink. In doing this, you will heap burning coals on his head (Rom 12:19-20).”

blessings

Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Just To Please The King, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

2 Sam 23:15, David longed for water and said, “Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!” So the three mighty men broke through the Philistine lines, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem and carried it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out before the LORD.   “Far be it from me, O LORD, to do this!” he said. “Is it not the blood of men who went at the risk of their lives?” And David would not drink it. Such were the exploits of the three mighty men.

David was the King that had a desire, water.  He didn’t give a command, he didn’t make his request part of his men’s job description, and he didn’t have an expectation that these three men should take up the task of his “craving” for water from Bethlehem.  This King was in the line of Jesus Christ as reads in Matt 1:1 “A record of the genealogy of Jesus Christ the son of David, the son of Abraham:”

Three mighty men: Utmost loyalty, sheer courage and bravery, along with evident sacrifice were the characteristics that these three men displayed in their venture.  They were loyal to David in that whom else would they have done this for going way beyond “the call of duty.”  They were brave and courageous with only three of them breaking through the host of the Philistine army after their twelve mile journey to get there.  These men could not just walk up to the well because of the Philistine garrison (outpost) in Bethlehem.  They broke through enemy lines, retrieved the water, and brought it back to David.  These men sacrificed their very lives not to gain clout or merit for themselves, not to be in the Israeli hall of fame, and not even to advance the victory for their army.  No, these men had on thing on their minds, to bring some water to their king!  Why, because this is what would please the King.  With loyalty and honor they risked their lives, “counting their lives worth nothing,” just to please the King to which they longed to do.  This King gave them identity and purpose and they put themselves in “death’s way,” to bring him pleasure.   Haggai 1:8 reads, “Go up into the mountains and bring down timber and build the house, so that I may take pleasure in it and be honored,” says the LORD”.  God is our King and desires me to please Him!

David’s Honor Response: It almost looks like a TV sitcom in this next scene.  David takes this water that the men risked their lives for and what does he do, POURS IT OUT on the ground.  It almost makes no sense. However, he pours it out onto the ground as it represented these three men’s blood sacrificed for the King.  Drinking the water to him was like drinking their blood in the risk of their lives.  David in a sense also made a sacrifice in putting the love of his men, before his own pleasure by spilling out the water he could have had as king.

1.      Would I (You) risk my (your) life and go above and beyond the call of duty just to please my King Jesus?        2.      How appreciative am I (are you) that Christ spilled His blood out for my (your) salvation amidst the circumstances in my life right now?        3.      Am I (you) breaking through enemy lines, winning souls for Christ just to please the heart of my King?

Search me O my Savior, Redeemer and Friend and let me hear your voice to please you with my life above and beyond the call of duty.  I hear your will Lord and as Isaiah said, “hear am I Lord, send me!”

Blessings,

Pastor Phil.

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 37:4, “Delight yourself also in the LORD, And He shall give you the desires of your heart”

I received an email yesterday with the question, “How to find God’s will for your life”. This is one of those topics I have no direct answer  to. Looking at it from the way I have walked with the Lord has led me to know what His will for my life is. I still don’t know what His will is in certain areas of my life but I can see the direction I am being led to. I have shared from this topic before but for the sake of the new people and those who are struggling, may this word ignite something in your spirit.

I believe that for someone to know the will of God they must first know God, I don’t mean know “about God” but actually “know God”. When you see things that He responds to, things that bring glory to His name, things that He does not approve of etc then you know what to do. All these are revealed in His word. His word becomes the manual book. Romans 10:17, “Faith comes by hearing and by hearing the word of God”. This is the beginning to understanding the will of God (Seek ye first) before knowing the will of God for your life (And all these other things shall be added unto you”. His word teaches us what God is like so us to respond according to His word. When you know God, you begin to learn your position in His kingdom; you begin to look for opportunities to operate in your position. Knowing God brings a massive change as in all about yourself is sifted and He fills you with more of Him.

Proverbs 10:32, “The lips of the righteous knows what is acceptable”. This scripture, talks about the “righteous”, those who Christ lives in their lives, those who have been made new creatures know what pleases Christ because they have learnt from Him. These are the ones with new appetites stirred up by Christ living inside. Anything that comes at this time is no longer for selfish desires but seeking opportunities to make Him shine.

Psalm 37:4 “Delight yourself also in the LORD”. The word “DELIGHT” means to take great pleasure. This as an opportunity to please the Lord with my life style because of what I have learnt from Him. In the book of Genesis, Cain and Abel brought sacrifices before God. Cain brought what he had done by himself and God did not receive it, Abel on the other hand brought that which the Lord required, a blood sacrifice. He was bringing to God what would please Him and he was offering it to God by faith. Remember again, “Faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of God”. Abel was delighting himself in the Lord. How did I know what God required? I learnt it from His word and I began to seek opportunities to glorify Him in all that I was doing. How did I know His will? Through promptings also confirmed by people, through a gift I never had, by thought He dropped in my mind, by leading and by me seeking opportunities according to His written will. What do all these have in common? They were to bring GLORY TO HIS NAME. This has been my way of delighting myself in the Lord. God is faithful because when you recognize that it’s not about you, He raises you to greater levels, gives you a blessing you were never qualified for simply because you delight in Him.

“And He shall give you the desires of your heart”, this scripture can be misapplied and you know why? Because anyone can have ugly, selfish or wrong desires but here is the key, when you delight yourself in the Lord, He will show you things He has stored for you in His vault. You begin to have an appetite for it, it becomes the desires of your heart and God who showed you steps out and gives it to you as His will for your life. There are many who will never progress because they are waiting to hear God speak audibly, at times God will just open a door and you will need to walk through it. At times He will give you a thought and expect you to begin to develop on that thought as He works with you but it all begins with delighting in the Lord. I have learnt more that the more I sought opportunities to glorify Him in what I do, the more He blessed what I was doing and the more He blessed me. That is how I have progressed to be a prayer warrior, a teacher of the word, a minister through devotions, a preacher, witnessing on the streets, encouraging others and even counseling etc, I know because I know Him, it’s all about glorifying Him

Blessings

Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalm 100:1-5, 1 Make a joyful shout to the LORD, all you lands! 2Serve the LORD with gladness; Come before His presence with singing. 3Know that the LORD, He is God; It is He who has made us, and not we ourselves;[1] We are His people and the sheep of His pasture. 4Enter into His gates with thanksgiving, And into His courts with praise. Be thankful to Him, and bless His name. 5For the LORD is good; His mercy is everlasting, And His truth endures to all generations. You’ve heard me say this before, it’s very important to start your day on a good note, it has a way of affecting your entire day if started well. To be honest with you, I tend to be very busy and spent many times but it matters a lot to me how I start my day.

We all have a way of affecting how we start the day, it’s a choice we have to make and declare otherwise we become victims of stress, frustrations and lack joy trying to do what is right. The bible tells us that the joy of the Lord is our strength. If we take a close look at the word joy, it’s more than happiness for happiness tend to go with how you feel at a given time especially when everything is going right, on the other hand, joy comes when you know that regardless of what you have to deal with whether going forward or backward, you will make it in other words rejoicing in the end result rather than the process. The joy of the Lord should make us comfortable in the situation we are in. You can be in a storm and still sleep comfortably.

Psalm 100 is a psalm of joy and singing, it starts with make a joyful shout to the Lord. I don’t have to shout joyfully to be heard by people, I can shout inside and when my inside is affected, definitely my outside appearance will be the result of what is going on inside. Serving the Lord with gladness is awesome for I know that whenever I sit to work at my station, I’m working and serving the Lord. This is a blessed time where I come in the morning to work and say Lord, “I thank you for another opportunity to serve you in my department and serve others that I may shine for You at my work place”. You see His word says in 1 Corinthians 10:31, “Therefore, whether you eat or drink, or whatever you do, do all to the glory of God”. Come before His presence with singing. I believe that music is the greatest tool used to uplift or to depress. There is nothing that people respond to like music and that is why we listen to music over and over again, we can have hundreds of music collections. The bible says that the Lord inhabits the praises of His people and we do a lot of praises through singing and listening to music. I love listening to music, it soothes and encourages but more so, it gives glory to God, it makes Him look good. A song in you will help you go through the day. When King Saul was being tormented by evil spirits, guess what they did, they had David playing music in his presence and the more he played, the more the evil spirit  could not be near him. Replace your worries and anxieties with a song in your ear, a song on your lips.

Enter into His gates with thanksgiving and into His courts with praise. I love this line for this reminds me to go beyond where I am. Entering into His gates and into His courts allows me to leave outside everything that will interfere with my praise while I’m serving Him everyday. There is power in thanksgiving and when I enter into His gates, I begin to see what He has done more and thank Him for His faithfulness. This is a choice everyone has to make, yes we will have so much on our plates to accomplish and yes we will be dealing with tough customers on the phone, but we have been given the power to change the course of the day by allowing the joy of the Lord to be our strength. Keep a song with you, enter His gates and into His courts with a thanksgiving in your heart, refuse anything that will steal your praise, thanksgiving heart, and joy and be a beacon of light right where God has placed you. I’ve made up my mind to start and finish the day well: I’ve said it, I mean it and I’m here to represent it. Will you do the same? !!!!! Blessings Evans

title.rendered: Fed By Obeying His Will, By Pastor Phil <

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“But he said to them, “I have food to eat that you know nothing about.” “My food,” said Jesus, “is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish his work.” (John 4:32,34)

Have you ever tried to share something with someone and they just didn’t comprehend what you were saying?  Jesus seemed to run into that situation often, even though He was a Master communicator.  Jesus had just finished having a conversation with a woman at the well, when His disciples were approaching with lunch.   His disciples “were surprised to find him talking with a woman.”  It was considered improper for a Rabbi to speak with women in public, let alone one that was sexually immoral.  The disciples then see the woman leave, and see her water bucket that she left as evidence of her presence, and not “just their imaginations.”  But no one asked, ‘What do you want?’ or ‘Why are you talking with her?’  I believe, that although no one asked those questions, those were the questions that they had on their minds.

His disciples had these questions, but didn’t dare ask them.  Therefore, what do men do when they don’t want to speak about what is really on their minds?  They eat!  Eating doesn’t take much brain power, similar to watching TV.  They urged Jesus, “Rabbi, eat something.”  Jesus however knowing their thoughts replies, “I have food to eat that you know nothing about.”  Now they are thinking that someone came and gave Him food.   Jesus continues by saying, “My food,” said Jesus, “is to do the will of him who sent me and to finish His work.”  Now they were really thrown off.  What was Jesus getting at, because they were talking about food, but Jesus wasn’t talking about food, He was talking about FOOD!  What was this food?

1.      The fulfillment Jesus received having ministered to this lost woman.

2.      The overall life mission of reconciling the world to the Father through Himself as the bridge.

3.      The sustenance of pleasing His Father by obeying the mission that He gave Jesus to live out.

4.      The very hunger He possessed, they did not yet crave, and that is being salt to make sinners thirsty for the water that the woman received.

What was the work Jesus was to finish?  Just as drinking from the well would cause the woman to thirst again, so too will the disciples hunger again if their food source was from town supermarket.  The woman needed the living water, and the disciples needed the bread of life, and the desire to seek and save the lost just as Jesus had.  When the woman was filled with the water of life she began to bring others to Jesus, and that is what Jesus was looking for in His Twelve.    “Do you not say, ‘Four months more and then the harvest’? I tell you, open your eyes and look at the fields! They are ripe for harvest. 36 Even now the reaper draws his wages, even now he harvests the crop for eternal life, so that the sower and the reaper may be glad together. 37 Thus the saying ‘One sows and another reaps’ is true. 38 I sent you to reap what you have not worked for. Others have done the hard work, and you have reaped the benefits of their labor.”  Jesus wanted the eyes of the disciples opened to the fields, NOT to their “food!” Job said, “I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my daily bread.”  Jesus told you and me to seek and save the lost.  When we obey God in this, we too will eat the food that many do not know of.  Are you hungry?  Go to the harvest fields of your schools and jobs, and finish the work by the power of the Holy Spirit, and be fed by obeying His will!

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

John 17:17- Sanctify them by thy truth, thy word is truth To sanctify is to consecrate, to dedicate entirely to God, to purify internally by renewing of the soul. To separate from common use, and to engage solely in the work of the divine, to truly obtain in one’s heart a holy ambition, a desire for holiness. Here is the heart of our Savior, He prays that we might be sanctified, cleansed by His word, enjoying the fullness of His work, to the praise, honor, and glory of Jesus Christ, our great redeemer.

In Ephesians 5:25-26, Paul writes, “Christ also loved the church, and gave Himself for her, that He might sanctify and cleanse her with the washing of water by the word.” Here again, we see His work was to sanctify us, to devote us entirely to Him and to cleanse us and make us holy, and again His word is identified as the purifying agent, the means by which we can be made pure. In this sacred text is found the keys to unlock all the abundance of Heaven, the fullness of the work of Christ in each life. I pray that we would each grasp today the depth of work our Lord died to do in us. Hebrews  13:12 says,” Jesus also, that He might sanctify the people with His own blood, suffered outside the gate.” Here again, Christ suffered and died to sanctify us, to make for Himself a holy nation, a people dedicated to Him entirely, a people that love Him with ALL of their heart, not just the part not consumed by worldly affections and desires.

Brother and sisters, let us be in the world, but not of the world. Let us be this day a separate people, sanctified unto our God, for this is the high calling of God in Christ, to be solely devoted to Him, and this work is done as we fill our souls with Him, in prayer and study, allowing Him to wash us of not just the stains of sin, but of everything within us that would offend the eyes of His majesty. Is there jealousy in you today? Are wrath, drunkenness, unholy ambition, and the like residing in your bosom? Did you immediately say no to those questions? If so, look closer, look to the word of God, the great purifier, the refiner of men’s souls, does your righteousness exceed that of the scribes and Pharisees(Matt 5:20)? Jesus died that He might sanctify us, that He might cleanse us, but His work is limited by our willingness. Let us resolve this day to dedicate ourselves entirely to Him and His will for our lives, for a baptism of holiness and a true demonstration of Godly living is the crying need of our day, and Christ has made all available to us by His willing sacrifice. I pray we would each willingly lay our lives down as well, living out our days for His glory, setting our eyes and our hearts upon the eternal, knowing this place is only temporary, and that he that does the will of God (I John 2:17, I Thess. 4:3) shall abide forever.

In the sincere love of Christ, and all for His glory,

Brother Ben

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 9:37, “Then He said to His disciples, “The harvest truly is plentiful, but the laborers are few 38, “Therefore pray the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into His harvest.”

While Jesus was on the face of the earth, He was limited to time and space. Only one place at a time could He be in. He was stretched in the life span of three years of His ministry on earth and I would say  He worked overtime. Matthew 8:20, “And Jesus said to him, “Foxes have holes and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay His head.” While the disciples slept, He labored at night in prayers and did ministry during day time. He did not have an organized structure, He wasn’t a pastor of an organized church meeting in a place but indeed He was a Shepherd. Being that He was limited to time and space, He did the much He could do and left the rest for the disciples and us who came along to continue with the great work.

Matthew 9:37, “Then He said to His disciples, “The harvest truly is plentiful, but the laborers are few”, Looking around, I am witness of the harvest truly being plentiful. We can act like it’s not but the truth of the matter is, it is indeed. As the harvest is plentiful guess what, the devil is working overtime when believers are seating on their pews singing “Amazing grace”. Wars have increased, kidnappings, rapes, murders, abortion, disobedience, hatred, rebellion, lawlessness, all these have increased because the devil is working overtime. Think about it, temptations are working overtime, fear is doing the same and the devil is putting off fires in believers who are careless to discern the time they are living in. Many are naming the name of Christ thinking they are safe but here is something to think about, “in our societies it’s always INNOCENT till proven GUILTY; in Christ, GUILTY till proven INNOCENT. Can you see how the harvest is plenteous? yes we have people who have never repented and received Christ and they know it and then there are those who are deceiving themselves to thinking they have Him simply because they mention His name. The harvest is plenteous and we as believers have to wake up from doing regular hours to doing overtime to win that which is lost.

Vs 38, “Therefore pray the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into His harvest.” I used to think that by being called to be a prayer warrior, I was suppose to pray that God would raise up other people to do the work only to discover that the more I prayed to God to raise up laborers, the more I realized that I was the answered prayer. You pray for laborers and you become the laborer you’ve been praying for. Imagine a blind man walking towards the cliff, you can see that this is what will kill him. You stand there and pray that God will raise someone to run and tell him to turn around. You and I have a moral obligation to tell the blind men walking towards the cliff to turn around. Check this, James 5:19, “Brethren, if anyone among you wanders from the truth, and someone turns him back, 20, let him know that he who turns a sinner from the error of his way will save a soul from death and cover a multitude of sins”. It’s a blessing to know that God could use you to save a soul. There is so much to be done and very few people to do it. The ones who could do the work have been consumed by structures, programs and traditions. There is nothing wrong with that but at the expense of the lost? If we continue to sit and do nothing, the enemy will continue to work overtime. We better rise up and begin to do overtime, you might not see the payoff immediately but the One who holds the universe has your records of faithfulness in the back of His mind. God help me to be faithful in harvesting, help me work overtime, go out of my way. Correct me if I am wrong, overtime is time and a half or double time right? I wouldn’t be surprised if the Lord blessed you more as you are faithful, but one thing to think about as one preacher mentioned it in his preaching, “since when did obedience make you special?”. Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Philippians 4:19, “But my God shall supply all your need according to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus”

Our Heavenly Father takes pleasure in providing for His children. He is the God of too much, the bible says, “A thousand cattle on the hills belongs to Him“, “Riches and Glory are His“, The God of the impossibilities. He knows each of His children in and out and He knows all their needs. He knows how to give good things to His children. Matthew 7:11, “If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your Father who is in heaven give good things to those who ask Him!”. He gives good things, not corrupt, broken, despised, or rejected. He gives the best to His own, He does it with joy, pleasure and gladness, and He gives with all of His heart. Psalm 23:1, “The Lord is my Shepherd, I shall not lack (AMP)”. The work of a shepherd is to feed, guide, protect, inspects His sheep, with Him being a Shepherd He guarantees His provision.

None of us qualifies for a blessing but each of us desire a blessing and the Father takes pleasure in blessing His children, David says in Psalm 37:25, “I have been young, and now am old; Yet I have not seen the righteous forsaken, Nor his descendants begging bread“. The more we walk with the Lord, the more we see how faithful He is even when we are faithless. The blessing is not reserved for those who are perfect; He desires to bless those who are His. You agree with me that there are many of the unsaved that God has blessed. More blessings does not mean more love and also does not mean He prefers more blessed than less blessed. The bible says, “He shows mercy to whoever He wants to show mercy, and grace to whoever He wants to show grace”.

We are all looking to God to supply our needs, some have financial needs, healing needs, guidance, strength, hope, you name it. When you know that no one else can come to your rescue but the one who created you, you will run to Him knowing that He is faithful. The Philippians had been a blessing to Paul. Paul’s needs were met by God through the Philippians and he in turn encouraged them saying “my God shall supply all your need”, not some of their needs but all their needs. If you need it, God will supply you with it. What a blessing to know that His supply is greater than demand. That He has a lot of ways to bless you, He could use a means you were not even expecting or a person who you were not thinking about. Paul was not expecting the Philippians to bless him but God used them anyway.

3 John 1:2, “Beloved, I pray that you may prosper in all things and be in health, just as your soul prospers“, God is not only concerned about your spiritual life, He is concerned about your physical needs too. He is concerned about your family (wife, husband, children, parents), He is concerned about your health Psalm 103:3, “…who heals all your diseases“, he is concerned about your finances, in short, He is concerned about your well being. All you have to do is ask, Hannah asked for a son, Hezekiah asked for a prolonged life, Jabez asked for a blessing, Samson asked for strength, Paul asked for boldness to preach the gospel, they all asked according to His will and He supplied according to His riches in glory by Christ Jesus. Remember today that God takes pleasure in providing for His children. Blessings Ev

NB: Please keep Dana’s family (Pastor Phil’s Friend), in your prayers. Dana lost her brother in law in a motorcycle accident. May the Lord supply them with grace and strength during this tough time.

title.rendered: A Sure Cure For the Blues, By Pastor Phil (Inspired by Charles Swindoll – Elijah)

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Elijah was afraid and ran for his life. When he came to Beersheba in Judah, he left his servant there, But he himself went a day’s journey into the wilderness, and came and sat down under a juniper tree: and he requested for himself that he might die; and said, It is enough; now, O LORD, take away my life; for I am not better than my fathers.” 5 Then he lay down under the tree and fell asleep. All at once an angel touched him and said, “Get up and eat.”  1 Kings 19:3-4

The following is a message that I was deeply inspired by from Charles Swindoll’s book Elijah, about the time in Elijah’s life when he went from victory to depression.  Here are some great truths for us to learn:

Firstly, Elijah was not thinking realistically or clearly. Who made the threat?  It was Jezebel not God that came against Elijah.  How was Elijah able to so boldly challenge 450 prophets of Baal, but yet this one woman caused him to feel so threatened and vulnerable to his core?  Often it’s the little things that we make bigger than God in our eyes that seem to threaten all that we hold dear, and all that we identify with.

Secondly, Elijah separated himself from strengthening relationships. Why did he get alone?  Often when one is depressed one tends to retreat to be by oneself, instead of connecting as one should, often one will disconnect at the time he or she so desperately needs others.  However when this happens others are pushed away and whatever encouragement others try to give, it is appreciated but not received or heard as much as it is needed.  One looks inward and refuses for a time to look outward.

Thirdly, Elijah was caught in the backwash of a great victory.  Often after a victory, often comes temptation and vulnerability.  Elijah previously battled against and proved that God NOT Baal is the true God that manifested Himself by answering by fire.

Fourthly, Elijah was physically exhausted and emotionally spent.  When we are in this state, our spirit is affected.  We tend to drag, become sluggish, tired, weary in well doing, etc….

Fifthly, Elijah got lost in self-pity. Have you ever had the “victim mentality,” whereby you blamed the world, “the system,” and everyone and everything else for your unhappiness?  The blame game has been played since Adam blamed Eve when he was questioned by God.  When we are in self pity, as far as we are concerned we are the only one with problems, and they are larger than life, even greater than the Lord.  God will not allow us to stay in self – pity if we are following Him, because He has too much for us to do, and to come to glorify His name in victory, and not in defeat.

God’s ministered to Elijah. God allowed Elijah a time of rest and refreshment.  God communicated wisely with Elijah (v.9), and gave Elijah a close personal friend (v.19-21) ELISHA.

Elijah reminds us. Let’s look up after the Lord graciously delivers us from our depression. Let’s look up when he allow us rest and refreshment following an exhausting schedule that has taken its toll on us. Let’s look up and thank Him when He gently and patiently speaks to us from his Word after we’ve climbed out of a pit of self-pity. Let’s look up and praise Him when He faithfully proved the companionship and affirmation of a friend who understands and encourages us. Let’s look up and acknowledge the Giver more than the gift.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Exodus 33:17, “So the LORD said to Moses, “I will also do this thing that you have spoken; for you have found grace in My sight, and I know you by name.” 18 And he said, “Please, show me Your glory.”

The other day I was reading some comments posted on line in response to a certain article about Christianity. Most of the comments were hard to read, God is hated out here. I remember back in the day where even if people did not serve God, at least they had a little reverence for Him. Today we have God haters.

We have a generation that has lost the fear of God, and we can see by what people are embracing and making it seem like the Almighty God is fine with their sin, after all God’s main job is to make man happy. Jesus came on the face of the earth to die to make man happy, so why not embrace the sin, we love the most as long as we are happy and God will indeed bless us. God is a means to an end. No fear of God because most have not had a glimpse of the glory of God. I would categorize this group as God accommodators.

When God was leading the Israelites to the Promised Land, in the previous chapter, they made idols for themselves to worship and even concluded that that their golden calf was their deliver from Egypt. In Exodus 33:3, God tells Moses to go and tell the Israelites that they were stiff necked people because of their rebellion, stubbornness, complaints (sin); today Moses would be labeled judgmental, cruel, unloving, unkind, and insensitive.

God even said, “I will let you go to the promise land but without my presence going with you” some would have been ok with that, and so are people who want to go to heaven today, they want to be partakers of God’s blessings but don’t want God. As Paul Washer always says, “These are people who want to go to heaven; they just hope God is not there when they get there.”

God called Israelites stiff necked people. Moses may have wondered, “how are they stiff-necked people, yes they complained, but they were not that bad” and if anything, God shouldn’t get worked up because these are His people He brought out of Egypt by Moses but God knew them better. Are we not in  the same state today that even some Christians find it hard or don’t believe that man is wretched, stiff necked? Again it boils down to, loss of fear of God for people have not had a glimpse of God’s glory.

God would have brought them under the yoke of His law, and into the bond of His covenant, but their necks were too stiff to bow to them. God would have cured them of their corrupt and crooked dispositions, and have set them straight; but they were willful and obstinate, and hated to be reformed, and would not have God to reign over them.

Vs. 4 “When the people heard these distressing words, they began to mourn and no one put on any ornaments” NIV. Those whom God pardons, must be made to know what their sin is, and what they deserve. God calls sin as it is, that is why we must preach the law to the lost, it magnifies God. God reveals Himself in the spirituality of His law. That is where His righteousness and perfect purity of character are revealed for men to learn it there. The beauty of God’s holiness will not allow Him to gloss over sin. His law magnifies Him, and for sinners, “Having thus removed the mask and shown the desperate case of the sinner, the relentless law causes the offence to abound yet more by bringing home the sentence of condemnation. It mounts the judgment seat, puts on the black cap, and pronounces the sentence of death. With a harsh unpitying voice, it solemnly thunders forth the words, “Condemned already.” It bids the soul prepare its defense, knowing well that all apologies have been taken away by its former work of conviction. The sinner is therefore, speechless, and the law, with frowning looks, lifts up the veil of hell, and gives the man a glimpse of torment. The soul feels that the sentence is just, that the punishment is not too severe, and that mercy it has no right to expect; it stands quivering, trembling, fainting, and intoxicated with dismay, until it falls to prostrate in utter despair. The sinner puts the rope around his own neck, arrays himself in the attire of the condemned, and throws himself at the foot of the King’s throne, with but one thought, “I am vile”; and with one prayer, “God be merciful to me a sinner.” Charles Spurgeon. Man must have knowledge about self as stiff necked people; otherwise he will never bow before the just and holy God. Only God’s glory displayed through the law can bring him to that state, and God haters become God lovers, and God accommodators get done with themselves, dethrone themselves and submit to God’s righteousness

To continue…

title.rendered: Between a Rock and a Hard Place, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning

I think we’ve all faced times in our lives when we felt like we were in a situation and all the options seemed to be trouble. I think of Harrison Ford in the Indiana Jones movies because his character always seemed to find himself in such a position.  He would be in a situation where on one side men with swords were attacking him, and on the other side the spiked walls would be caving in on him.  Somehow he always came out alive and with his hat on as well.  That is Hollywood, but life plays some similar situations toward us at times. When one is between a rock and a hard place, going forward is trouble, going back is dangerous, and remaining in place is disastrous.  This is where Israel found herself when Moses led them out of Egypt, out of bondage only to stand before the great Red Sea in Exodus 14:13 – 16.

“Moses answered the people, “Do not be afraid. Stand firm and you will see the deliverance the LORD will bring you today. The Egyptians you see today you will never see again. Ex 14:14 The LORD will fight for you; you need only to be still.” Ex 14:15 Then the LORD said to Moses, “Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelites to move on. Ex 14:16 Raise your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea to divide the water so that the Israelites can go through the sea on dry ground.” There are some great promises and challenges in this passage of Scripture and they are as follows:

  1. God sees the situation behind you and instructs you not to fear.

If Israel were to go back they saw themselves being slaughtered by the Egyptian Army.  As humans fear can be thought of as a natural human trait, but there are so many verses in which the Lord instructs us not to fear, and “If God is for us, who can be against us? (Rom. 8:31)”

2.   The Lord will fight for you, you need only to be still (remain)

If Israel were to stay in place they would be protected as long as God was there to protect them.  “Do not be afraid or terrified because of them, for the LORD your God goes with you; he will never leave you nor forsake you (Duet. 31:6).”  The Israelites had just seen the Lord previously bring down ten distinct plagues on the Egyptians and the Israelites had no part to play in causing any of the plagues to hit their enemies.

3.    Don’t sit there are cry about it, Move on!

God called to move on, but to where into the Sea?  This initially presented a major problem until the Lord gave further instructions.  God gave Moses the command to raise his staff and stretch it over the sea to divide the waters so that a dry new road could be made without the use of construction machinery, builders, contracts or blueprints.  Despite resources God can use the ordinary things of ours to do extraordinary things when we obey Him as we use the common object which in this case was a shepherd’s staff.  I can picture in the natural Moses stretching out his staff over the Sea, and in the Supernatural God using His hands to part the waters.  God had a plan of how to move on, but Moses needed the faith to extend his staff, and walk between the two walls of water.  The Lord encourages you not to go back or to fear the past and that He will fight for you in the present as you remain still.  However, when God tells you to move you had better get going because that is where the miracle is.  Where are you currently?  Recognize God’s will at each stage.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Exodus 33:17, “So the LORD said to Moses, “I will also do this thing that you have spoken; for you have found grace in My sight, and I know you by name.” 18 And he said, “Please, show me Your glory.”

For a few weeks now, I’ve been meditating on this word “GLORY”, and the very key scripture that brought this about is the very famous verse quoted in reaching the lost, Romans 3:23, “for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God”. Have you ever wondered why the end of that verse does not say, “…fall short of God’s moral standard?”. Think about Isaiah 6:3, “Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; The whole earth is full of His glory!”, it does not finish with what it started. If it started with “holy” repeated three times, you would expect Isaiah to conclude by saying, “the whole earth is full of His holiness” instead he says, “The whole earth is full of His glory”. There is something about “HIS GLORY” that everything ties into; I hope we can get a little glimpse of this word “glory”, the revelation of God.

“The Glory of God” is an important theme in the book of exodus, and it is the first time I see it introduced in the books of the bible. It appears in relation to the deliverance and wandering in the wilderness, the ratification of the covenant and the tabernacle. It could be concluded that a discussion on this theme should be related to a discussion on the being and attributes of God. In the OT, however, “glory” is the visible and supernatural manifestation of the supreme and incomparable majesty of God. According to the commentary I read, the Hebrew word for “glory” is (kabod), which means “weight” or “substance” and comes to mean the honor stemming from the manifestation of the sum total of God’s attributes, and also from the awe which such a revelation inspires those who behold it. Pastor John Piper describes it this way, “The glory of God is the manifestation of His holiness. God’s holiness is the incomparable perfection and greatness of His divine nature; His glory is the display of that holiness. His glory is the open revelation of the secret of His holiness. When God shows Himself to be holy, what we see is His glory—the beauty of holiness. The holiness of God is His concealed glory. The glory of God is His revealed holiness.” In summary, “The glory of God is the infinite beauty and greatness of His manifold perfections”, John Piper

And here we see that Moses say, “Please, show me Your glory”, the glory fall we all fall short of.  Having a little bit described the “glory of God”; I can understand why in preaching the gospel we need to start with the glory of God.  Imagine you are told of a very important person you are going to meet. You may have despised his name when you heard it. You have heard of bad things that have happened while he was in leadership, and you came up with every thought you could imagine about this person as being such a bad person compared to you. But as they continue to describe this important person you have to stand before, his qualities, his attributes, his likes, his preference,  what has been concealed to you is being displayed. Would that not drive you to start thinking of how unworthy you are to stand before such an important person? You look at who you are, where you’ve been, what you’ve done etc and everything good you thought about yourself falls short having heard a description of this important person? That was Isaiah’s experience in Isaiah 6, no one told Isaiah of his sins, he saw the holiness of God, His righteousness, His majesty, how great He is, how marvelous, how powerful, His omnipotence, His sovereignty etc, all summed up in two words, “HIS GLORY”. I can imagine him saying, “how can I stand in a glory like that in my state? I’m unworthy, He is not like me, He deserves more than this, I’ve fallen short of His requirement to stand before Him. Isaiah did not start with himself as the measuring standard (sinners do), He started with God in His glory, “please, show me Your glory”.

Then the questions to ask yourself is who am I? the crowing glory of the creation of God, why I’m I here?, “to bring glory and honor to the Lord Jesus Christ”, what is wrong with the world?, me. I don’t do what I was meant to do, Romans 1:21, “…although they knew God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor were thankful, but became futile in their thoughts, and their foolish hearts were darkened”, while other religions may teach how to make it by being good. Be happy by all means by being religious, and even try not to do bad things for fear of punishment or karma, we glorify God because we have seen Him in His glory and His glory has revealed to us our unworthiness and how in our state we would not stand before Him. We have seen the beauty of His holiness revealing to us that in our life we are not bringing him the glory and honor He deserves and only Christ can redeem us, restore us and clothe us with His righteousness. Now our only motivation, our drive, our desire, our passion is, “BE THOU GLORIFIED”. Thank you Lord for showing me Your glory. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Dealing With Your Mistakes, by Boaz Olang

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Mistakes are inevitable occurrences in life. We all make mistakes deliberately, accidentally or unconsciously. Whatever the case may be, there are always consequences of our mistakes. In nearly all cases, the consequences are never pleasant or desirable. It is usually very hard to predict accurately what the consequences of our mistakes might be and how they will impact our life and the life of those around us.

I would like to refer you to two incidents in the Bible in which two good people made mistakes that bore very grave consequences that almost ruined or cost them their life and relationships. The first case is that of Esau, the eldest son of Isaac and the second is that of Joseph, the son of Jacob, Esau’s youngest brother. Esau sold his birthright. Joseph bragged arrogantly and foolishly to his jealous brothers and un-discerning parents about his future. He didn’t know how to keep secrets. He had a wide mouth and was full of youthful pride, arrogance, stupidity and immaturity. He was power hungry. His mistakes put him in the pit and prison in Egypt. God’s hands, however, lifted him from the prison and placed him in Pharaoh’s palace, and was later made ruler of Egypt. God reversed his misfortune to fortune. Joseph learned from his mistakes. He forgave his brothers

Esau too made a big mistake. He sold his birth right to his younger brother for a bowl of soup because he was hungry. That bad and permanent decision he made in order to satisfy a temporary need cost him a lifetime loss of riches, honor, and happiness. Besides, that mistake later created a wedge between him and his brother Jacob. The consequences of Esau’s mistake were grave. His hunger was genuine and he needed to satisfy it. He did. Only he did it the wrong way. If he had learnt to be patient, thoughtful, prayerful, wise, he still would have been able, by God’s help, to find a good, proven and acceptable solution for his hunger. The spirit of anger followed hunger as Esau tried to deal with the aftermath of his mistake. Anger and hunger, are two dangerous physical and emotional drivers that are responsible for a lot of mistakes people make every day in life and the consequences of those mistakes.

Can you think of a time or occasion when you made a mistake, for instance, by saying or doing the wrong thing simply because you were hungry for something or angry at someone or something? Are you aware of what your anger or hunger might have cost you? Yes, hunger and anger, if not dealt with the right way, can be very costly regardless of whether you are born again or not. Many marriages, for instance, have ended because of mistakes inspired and inflated by hunger and anger. Parents and their children have created emotional distance between them because of anger and hunger. Good friendships have dissolved because of anger and hunger. Many have lost good jobs and missed opportunities for promotion and advancement because they were angry at the boss, company or because they were hungry for more money, power and prestige and were not willing to wait for these things to arrive on God’s time at right place, the right way. Worse of all, many have sold their Christian birthright and heritage and lost all the blessings and privileges that accompany salvation because of being angry at God. Angry because of thinking that God forsook them in times of their desperate need.

Like Esau and Joseph, we sometimes make honest, but silly mistakes. Mistakes can cause misfortunes. Learn to avoid or minimize them. How? Prove all things. Scrutinize your thoughts, actions before you act. “…That you may prove what is that good, acceptable and perfect will of God.” Romans 12:2. Learn to forgive and to give. It is more blessed to forgive and receive than it is to be forgiven and be given. “Forgiveness and giving, when practiced on a daily basis, are two practical activities that can stimulate amends, instigate reunions, and restore what was once wounded, lost or stolen.” Becky Tirabassi, “Change Your Life”. God bless you. Brother Boaz

title.rendered: As He Is, So Are We, by Brother Ben

content.rendered:
Good morning,
I John 4:17- Love has been perfected in us in this: that we may have boldness in the day of judgment; because as He is so are we in this world.

I design today to look at this verse in three parts. First, perfect love, described throughout scripture in various ways is the absence of the enmity that once resided, allowing the believer to render all of their affections unto God continuously. This is the culmination of God’s initial work in our hearts, allowing us to love the Lord our God with all of our heart, soul, mind , and strength(Mark 12:30). This is perfect love for God, this is “Christian Perfection.” This is the chief aim of God in every life, holiness of heart and life.

Boldness here speaks of confidence and assurance, birthed in the heart when the condemnation of sin is removed. Sin will always separate us from God, to sin willfully is to backslide, to fall away from God, therefore God designs to remove the enmity, the very warfare between us and Him. He desires unbroken fellowship with His beloved, but the self life will always draw us away from that fellowship. To have assurance we must be assured in our hearts that we are children of God, not sometimes, not on Sundays, but all the time! We must stir ourselves up friends, to lay hold of our Lord in prayer, believing by faith that the sanctifying power of His Spirit might fall upon our hearts in all its cleansing power.

The question remains here, are we as he is in this world? Are you walking daily in the Savior’s power, are you a reflection of Him? Are you daily dying to yourself, that His life might be manifested in your mortal flesh? Let us examine ourselves, opening our hearts to the searching of the Holy Spirit, removing from our hearts all things offensive to our Lord. Let us desire this day to give ourselves entirely to Him, surrendering body, mind, heart, and soul to the Lord.

This is the simplicity that is in Christ friends, the restoration of a relationship broken by sin, where God alone reigns in the heart, no other desire is known, all desires now flow from this love for the High and Holy One, and all within the heart is love. Fear, jealousy, pride, selfish ambition, anger, rage are removed, and we are rooted and fixed in God, abounding in love.

All for His glory, Brother Ben

title.rendered: Received strength…, devotion by Sis. Bala Samson

content.rendered:
Good morning,

I received this devotion and would like to share it with you. I pray that it be an encouragement to you. blessings Ev

Received strength…, devotion by Sis. Bala Samson

Hebrews 11:11 Through faith also Sara herself received strength to conceive seed, and she bore a child when she was past the age, because she judged him faithful who had promised.

Some of us feel we are not qualified to walk in faith, but notice today’s message points out to you that we “receive strength” from God to exercise our faith. Can we say Amen! Sarah “received strength to conceive!” Well, her strength to activate her faith to expect God to do a miracle through her, at such an advanced age of 90 came from God. Sometimes we feel, “it is too late”, “it is getting worst”, “is this possible”? The devil accuses us day and night. He likes to push us into dismay, because then we cannot be strong; but the Bible says, “be strong in the Lord” (Ephesians 6:10) Friend, we are not alone in the battle, God would give us the necessary strength to trust Him. I remember at one time during the initial stages of my ministry, I felt unqualified to do the Lord’s ministry, but eventually God gave me the strength to do it. I remember one midnight struggling within myself whether I should preach the next day or not, it was my first preaching experience in a prayer meeting, God clearly spoke to me through the Word that He would give me the strength to deliver the message. We all at one stage or the other, we face the ‘How’ test. “How am I going to do this when I’ve never done it before?”

A church in Boston refused to allow Dwight L. Moody to join because they said his beliefs seemed so uncertain. But this man turned out to be a great man of God and shook the world for Jesus. Amen. God would help you grow too, take heart friend!

We often look back on difficult times with a fond remembrance because we realize we grew the most there. I think faith is very similar. Perhaps we will look back on our life and realize that it was only after a time of question or doubt that we grew in faith and understanding. It motivated us to search and explore and pray and read. And we came away with an even greater faith.

Friend, it was not easy for Abraham and Sarah to trust God. Abraham received the promise for a child at the age of 75 but he had to go through many hardships, heart aches up to the age of 100, when he finally received the promise. The strength to wait, endure pain and sufferings comes from God. As we look at the example of Abraham and Sarah, we can see that it is God who does the enabling; it is God who gives the power to overcome the impossible; in each situation it is His work and His alone.

If there is sin in your life, please bring it to the Lord because sin can make you feel insecure and weak. Confess it and leave it. by Sis. Bala Samson

title.rendered: Expressions of a Thankful Person, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“He threw himself at Jesus’ feet and thanked him—and he was a Samaritan. Luke 17: 16

We are quick to complain and ask God for things, but slow to thank Him for the blessings already in possession and slow or non – existent to give thanks when He does answer prayer, provide, or protect.

How quickly we forget to thanks.  “Give credit where credit is due” how much credit does God deserve?  Do you treat God like a cosmic Santa Clause or a Heavenly Father?  I’ve heard it said that the Key to contentment is Thanksgiving. For the Christian, every day should be Thanksgiving Day. We should even be thankful in the midst of problems. The Apostle Paul said in 2 Cor. 7:4 have great confidence in you; I take great pride in you. I am greatly encouraged; in all our troubles my joy knows no bounds., ” He knew that God was working all things together for his good, even though he was going through trials (Romans 8:28). And we know that in all things God works for the good of those who love Him, who have been called according to His purpose

Jesus encounters 10 lepers that ask Him to have mercy on them.  Jesus conforms to Jewish norms by requiring that the lepers go for the required priestly declaration of health (cf. Lev 14).  Jesus teaches about the expressions of a thankful person.  To give thanks is to show gratitude, give admonition, and let gratefulness flow out of your heart in words and in deeds and to express that joy Godward!  Here are some expressions to learn from a thankful leper.

  • #1 Thanksgiving BEGINS with Recognition (V.13). All the lepers acknowledged Jesus as MASTER.  As you spend time with Jesus what are some names or titles you use to refer to Him as you recognize His rule over your life? Lepers were social outcasts that had body parts rotting away that would eventually fall off.  Perhaps there are areas in your life that seem to be “falling off” that you can’t seem to keep together.  There is no one that has it all together.   Maybe everything is not falling apart in your life, but there are areas that each of us feel handicapped in.  We need to recognize God’s power and mercy (“HAVE MERCY ON US).
  • # 2 Thanksgiving CONTINUES with Obedience (V.14). Upon asking for help from Jesus, He sent them to the priest and they obeyed Him.  As they were going (obeying) they were cleansed.  God does things in our lives as we are obeying Him.  He trusts us with a little and sees how obedient we are with what He has given us, before He will ever entrust us with more.  Jesus has commanded us to “GO” seek and save the lost.  Can this command given be seen as obedience in your life?  Jesus said “if you love me, you will obey me” (John 14:21)
  • #3 Thanksgiving is FULFILLED in Praise (V.15-16) Only 1 / 10 returned to give thanks, and Jesus recognizes that.  The leper gave active thanks.  He didn’t send a postcard, or e-mail, no way, he thanked Jesus personally!  His thanks came from his loud voice (he was not ashamed) Rom 1:16.  He Glorified God (not the priest).  In Humility he fell at the feet of Jesus. The world is unthankful “For although they knew God, they neither glorified him as God nor gave thanks to Him, but their thinking became futile and their foolish hearts were darkened.
  • #4 Thanksgiving RESULTS in Spiritual Healing. The Samaritan realized he was healed and “Made whole” which was not the same proclamation for the others. Jesus verbally recognized the man’s faith in the healing process, which could also be read, “Your faith has saved you” More than physical healing, but spiritual healing.  This man got something the other nine didn’t receive because he gave thanks.  God may withhold future blessings from you when you don’t give Him thanks, and recognition for what He has already done in your life.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings & Thanks, Pastor Phil<><
