title.rendered: Past Sins and Present Truth, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“But he that lacks these things is blind, and cannot see afar off, and has forgotten that he was purged from his old sins.  12 Wherefore I will not be negligent to put you always in remembrance of these things, though you know them, and be established in the present truth.” 2 Peter 1:9, 12

In second Peter, Peter lists ten virtues that should be in the life of a Christian in 2 Peter 1:5 – 7.   Peter goes on to say in light of the virtues, “For if you possess these qualities in increasing measure, they will keep you from being ineffective and unproductive in your knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.”  He then points out that those who lack such virtues are blind and thus have forgotten of the cleansing of one’s past sins.  He then goes onto implore that the Christian be established in the present truth.  The past is a time that perhaps many would like to go back and change, but one cannot go back in time, that is why it is called THE PAST.  Peter teaches us some very important lessons concerning our forgetting past sins, and our living in the present truth.

    1. God never wastes a pain.  Perhaps you, like I, have experienced some deep hurts from other people, and situations.  Who better to minister to someone that has been raped, than another believer that has been raped?  Who better to minister to someone that has been in financial crises, than someone else that have been over their heads in bills and not knowing where the moneys were going to come from.  God will not waste your pain, but in submission to Him, He will use your pain to bring honor and glory to Himself through it.

2.      Living in the Past blinds us from living in the present.  God desires that we learn from the past, but not live in the past, there is a BIG difference!  How can one move forward in Christ if one is still living in the past?  Remember when Israel wanted to go back to Egypt, the place of bondage, for the temporal pleasure of food?  Isn’t that just like some Christians at times, who choose rather go back to bondage because of a temporal pleasure.

3.      Be established in the truth.  To be established is to have one’s “house” built firmly upon the rock, Jesus Christ, rather than the shifting sands of this world.  Our lives at one time were built up on the sand of falsehood built by the enemy himself.  However God is calling His children to live in truth.  It’s easy to live a lie by staying away from the truth which is found in God’s Word.  Jesus said, “Sanctify them by the truth; your word is truth.” When one continues in the truth then one shows themselves to be a disciple of Christ (John 8;31), then the truth that one practices, puts into action, appropriates will set them free from the past.  God’s truth is described by Paul to be the belt. That the belt is tied tightly around the waist to indicate that the soldier is prepared for action. To loosen the belt was to go off duty.  Are you established in the truth or do you go off duty at times? Are you in God’s word which sanctifies and washes (Eph 5:26)? 

Remember that God is calling you and I to learn from the past and not live in the past.  He will never waste a pain, and will establish us in the truth by His Word, in His Word, and through His Word.  Then we are to take God’s truth and share our faith.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Pastor Phil <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Hebrews 12:1&2, “…and let us run with patience the race that is set before us, 2   Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; …” (KJV)

I recently shared on the subject of “patience”, it is vital for me to share more as there are some folks battling. Our patience is tested while on traffic; check out lines at the stores, at an entrance gate for a game and many more. We struggle with patience because we would rather be the ones in front of everyone else, which makes us selfish if you think about it. In as much as you would like to be the one in the front, the person in the front also deserves a chance. Then it all comes back to “it’s about me” (just an input but not the direction for the message today).

The word “patience” appears 33 times only in the NT if you read KJV and God is referred in Romans 15:5 as the God of patience. Would we say that the generation after the OT struggled with patience? I would say so. In OT, Moses, David, Abraham, Jacob, Isaac, Esther, Jeremiah, David, Naomi and others endured with patience to see God’s promises to them happen. Some did not see those promises come to pass in their lifetime yet at a distance, they embraced them.

The writer of Hebrews (not known) reminded believers including himself to run with patience the race set before them (us). Sometime back while watching the Olympics marathon, it was a 26-mile race that many turned out to run.. If you know marathon, it is the kind of race that requires proper practice/preparation, patience and endurance. It took the winner 2hrs 05 Mins to complete the race. As I was watching it, there were times the runners were running on plain ground, at times up a hill and in the hot sun, which made them slow down at times. The person who was at one point leading was pushed off his truck by one of the spectators. It did affect his speed and left him shaken but he would not quit the race. They were all running with patience, grabbing water to quench their thirst and cool them down. They were looking forward to the finish line. To some it did not matter if they were not first on the finish line, all that mattered was that they finished the race.

Our race with and in Christ is no different, it requires patience and endurance. It is a long journey but we are getting closer and closer to the finish line Romans 13:11, “…for now our salvation is nearer than when we first believed“. Our finish line is Jesus, we look to Him. You know of those who you started the race with Christ, some quit running and some reduced their speed tremendously but you have continued to run the race with your eyes fixed on Jesus. You and I are like the marathon runners running a race with endurance. Jesus ran His race here on earth with patience and a beautiful example is the process of His crucifixion. He could have just had someone spear Him to death and still He would have died for mankind but the bible says, “Christ must suffer“, that is patience and endurance there. Paul went through patience and endurance facing difficult times yet he would not quit why? because His eyes were fixed on Jesus the author and the finisher of his faith. Did he finish his marathon race even after all that? Yes, he did 2 Timothy 4:7, “I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.”  Despite the battles, he fought a good fight; despite the obstacles, he finished the race; despite the trials, he kept the faith and that is what I am looking forward to. It’s about being faithful till the end. I know of those times when this race gets so hard, so tiring, obstacles, barriers, trials and just like the rest, the feeling of quitting presents itself, the enemy keeps reminding you to quit. Didn’t He whisper the same to Jesus? All I know is that I am getting closer and closer as I run the race with patience. I am far from where I started and I am closer to where I am going. If I can just hang on a little while and keep looking to the One who can give me strength to finish the race, I will join Paul and many saints who finished the race with joy. We ought to be persevering saints, let us keep running. Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

John 1:46, “Nazareth! Can anything good come from there?” Nathanael asked. “Come and see,” said Philip. (NIV)

It is troubling to know you can be misjudged, misunderstood, misquoted. The word “miss” is referred to when something is absent in the whole picture. Not being able to hit the target or accomplish what one had in mind. It could be a piece of information or a piece of puzzle. What might not make sense to you could make sense to someone else simply because they have the other piece of information you do not have. You can type a whole sentence, a word missing or how you punctuate could change the whole meaning of the message you are trying to pass across. The other thing is to know the history of something and misjudge what it is capable of by looking at its history.

It is fascinating to know that Jesus was referred to as Jesus of Nazareth. The King of kings was not even born in an earthly kingdom though He qualified. He was raised up in a normal town called Nazareth the home of Joseph and Mary.  I don’t see   in the Old Testament where they mention Nazareth is mentioned until you get to the gospels, I could be wrong. Tying the pieces together as to how Nazareth would have been, it was no place for a King maybe because it had no class or the people had no great fear of God. And to think that the person who would come out of it and call Himself the King was non other than Joseph’s son, a carpenter.

Philip finds Nathanael and he gives him the good news vs. 45, “…”We have found Him of whom Moses in the law, and also the prophets, wrote–Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.” Would you be excited if you heard that the person you grew up with or watched their life style could become someone extra ordinary? I would dismiss that too. When you know someone in and out and knowing where they came from, it can be hard to see far beyond because you have already dismissed them. Even today and I am guilty of this too, I look at some people I know and dismiss what they can do. Ladies can look at men and dismiss them as not being good husbands (husband material); the same can happen to men. You look at a child who is growing up and all you see is disaster and your comments include something like, “you will never amount to anything”, you have already dismissed anything they could be. We have to be very careful not to dismiss people and things based on the little knowledge or information we have. As mentioned, one little tiny piece of information is enough to change the destination of what you see. Nathanael could not see anything good coming out of an ordinary place even after Phillip told him and it is because he did not have a tiny piece of information to complete the puzzle. Are we not like Nazareth where Christ would come out of? Instead of sitting on the throne, He has chosen to dwell in our hearts (Nazareth). He came right where we were in Nazareth to redeem us. He has chosen to be born in our hearts (Nazareth) the ordinary city. Did you ever think that one day you would be saved? Did you ever know that you would be used of God one day? Did you have people dismiss you and right out of you,  Jesus of Nazareth comes out of you? You were dismissed because the piece, “Christ in you” was not seen and because of that. Philippians 4:13, “I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me” could not be seen either. You might have been dismissed, that ought to humble you and I, God raises the least likely, the stones the builders rejected. He fills that life with His presence and leaves His life through that broken vessel. 1 Corinthians 1:27, “But God chose the foolish things of the world to shame the wise; God chose the weak things of the world to shame the strong“. You always have to watch out for the one who has been dismissed because there is an anointing in their life and God uses such. Though Nathaniel dismissed Nazareth, when he met Jesus, he was not the same again.  Blessings Evans

title.rendered: What Gathers And Assembles You? By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

When the seventh month came and the Israelites had settled in their towns, all the people assembled as one man in the square before the Water Gate. They told Ezra the scribe to bring out the Book of the Law of Moses, which the LORD had commanded for Israel. So on the first day of the seventh month Ezra the priest brought the Law before the assembly, which was made up of men and women and all who were able to understand.  He read it aloud from daybreak till noon as he faced the square before the Water Gate in the presence of the men, women and others who could understand. And all the people listened attentively to the Book of the Law.  Ezra praised the LORD, the great God; and all the people lifted their hands and responded, “Amen! Amen!” Then they bowed down and worshiped the LORD with their faces to the ground. (Neh. 8:1-3, 6)

What causes you to gather in large crowds with others?  Do you gather over birthdays, holidays, a birth of a child, a death of a loved one, a sporting event, a concert, a parade, a new movie, game, or music release etc…?  What does it take to bring you out?  People gather together usually because of a common interest.   The people in this passage gathered to hear God’s word.  Women” did not participate in ordinary meetings but were brought together with children on such solemn occasions (Deut 31:12; Josh 8:35; 2 Kings 23:2).  “All who were able to understand” is rendered “children old enough to understand” These people gathered to hear God’s Word.  It sounds like church, but they were more reverent toward the Lord than many seem to be in our “modern style of worship.”  “He read it aloud from daybreak [sunup] till noon as he faced the square,” and all the people diligently listened and were impacted by it.  How do we know the impacted?  “All the people lifted their hands and responded, ‘Amen! Amen!’ Then they bowed down and worshiped the LORD with their faces to the ground!” The key is this, these people didn’t just gather (a group of people crowding together), but they assembled.

Heb 10:24-25 read “And let us consider one another to provoke to love and to good works; Not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together, as the manner of some is; but exhorting on another; and so much more as we see the day approaching.”

Once you have gathered then we are instructed to assemble.  Sometimes when you purchase a product that comes in parts, the box will read “some assembly required”  All the pieces are gathered in the box but not assembled where they fit in by their design and purpose.  Think of a puzzle in a box, all the pieces are gathered but they are not yet assembled into the picture on the box.  We are instructed to reverently gather to hear the Word of God, and to engage His truth and this can be clearly seen by our active response, remembering of course that God sees our heart and can look through fabricated outward actions that please man and not Him.

Application:  As a Christian when you gather with other Christians do you assemble with them, in that you find your place in ministry and where you fit in so as to bless and benefit the body of Christ (see 1 Cor. 12)?  Do you engage the Word of God both in church and out? Blessings, Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 17:27, “….go to the sea, cast in a hook, and take the fish that comes up first. And when you have opened its mouth, you will find a piece of money;] take that and give it to them for Me and you.”

I hate being in debt, and I believe everyone does too. I do not like owing anyone, Romans 13:8, says, “Owe no man any thing, but to love one another:” To me this is a clear indication that even God hates to see His children in debt. That is why he had to do something about our debt of sin, the reason we pray Matthew 6:12, “Forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors”(NIV). Who in their right mind would want to owe someone else? And yet we find that we are debtors to other people. The most common debt of our day is financial debt. We owe the credit card companies, car payments, appliances, accumulated electrical and gas bills to mention a few. I believe with all my heart that debt can be a disease that needs to be cured before it destroys a Christian. Some bring this disease upon themselves being careless and misusing the resources God has provided for them and to some, life circumstances has brought them there.

In Matthew 17, it happened that Peter and Jesus owed the temple taxes. The bible says the wealth of the wicked is stored for God’s children right? How come Jesus knowing about this still was liable for taxes? Doesn’t the bible say, “the earth is the Lord’s and the fullness of it?”, This is to our learning. Yes we are the children of God and God provides for us but He will not let us ignore our responsibility to others (government, companies, those we owe).

Jesus turns to Peter and says, ““….go to the sea, cast in a hook, and take the fish that comes up first. And when you have opened its mouth, you will find a piece of money; take that and give it to them for Me and you.” Here is what got me, instead of Jesus calling money into existence and Peter could use to pay taxes, He gives him an instruction that is mind blowing. Backing up to Mathew 15, Jesus fed 4,000 with seven loaves of bread and few little fish. Why couldn’t He perform a miracle right there to clear up this debt? Why is it that we have Christians in debt who do not want to do anything about it? They are sitting and doing nothing hoping that God will perform a miracle right before their eyes and their debts will disappear. I know God can and we know of some people who have experienced it but we cannot limit God to one method of helping us deal with our problems. Isn’t it clear that if we owe, we should find a way to pay it back? And our prayer is Lord provide away, we want to owe man nothing? Jesus provides and Peter had a job to do and here is what he had to do, GO, CAST, TAKE, OPEN, FIND, GIVE. God can provide away for you to minimize or clear up your debt, not by calling money into existence but by leading you places to fish. He can provide by creating more work that would require overtime if they pay overtime. You may be required to take a part time job because that is what he has set a side as a way to provide for you. You have to go an extra mile with His help. Peter had to do the same, yes Jesus provided yet in a way Peter’s other abilities were required. Now Jesus did not ask Peter to do an impossible task because He already took care of that, He asked him to do what He knew He could give him strength to perform. What are you doing to pay your debts? Are you praying, Lord provide away then going an extra mile to fulfill what He has provided or are you doing nothing, less or just enough hoping it will go away. If you pray Lord provide away, don’t be surprised to hear GO, CAST, TAKE, OPEN, FIND, GIVE. Blessings Ev

title.rendered: Testing Truth, by Pastor Phil inspired by Josh McDowell

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“And now, O Israel, what does the LORD your God ask of you but to fear the LORD your God, to walk in all His ways, to love Him, to serve the LORD your God with all your heart and with all your soul, and to observe the Lord’s commands and decrees that I am giving you today for your own good? (Deut 10:12-13)

Step #1 Precepts – The rules, regulations, codes, and requirements of Scripture. “You shall not murder” He gave specific commandments like a parent telling their child not to touch a hot stove.

Gal. 3:24 states, 24 So the law was put in charge to lead us to Christ that we might be justified by faith.”  In the Greek speaking world of Paul’s day there was a role played by one of the household servants called the paidagogos.  He was responsible for the moral welfare and character development of a child.  One of his responsibilities was to take the child to school everyday, and make sure that the child was brought under the authority and care of the teacher.  Paul borrows from the culture of his day to show us that the law has the same function.  The commands of Scripture are not only designed to say “Do this,” and “Don’t do that,” but to lead us beyond the precept to a universal principle (one that applies to everyone) and ultimately to the God who expresses Himself through precept.

Step #2 Principles – If precepts are the first step toward knowing God, and distinguishing right from wrong, principles are the vehicle or stairway from leading us from precepts to the person of God.  Behind each command (precept) is a principle.  Principle is the why behind a command.  Most Christians don’t know why they believe what they believe.  A concern for safety is one of the principles for a mother’s command for her child to look before crossing the street so as not to end up as road kill.  In the events from 9/11, many saw more a reverence for life, a principle behind the command “You shall not kill.”

Step #3 – Person (of God). To know what we believe about God’s precepts and even the principles behind those precepts from whom they derive is worthless without the relationship.  Too many times when we focus on the law of God, we miss seeing its extensions – which it teaches us about the character, nature and person of God.  God is a person.

Moses when receiving the law on top of Mt. Sinai apparently understood this progression of precept-principle-person of God.  Ex 33:11 states that God spoke to Moses face to face, as a man speaks with his friend, Moses prayed, “If you are pleased with me teach me your ways that I may know you….” (Ex. 33:13) Moses realized that learning God’s way – understanding His precepts and the principles behind them – would acquaint him with the person of God.  Lying is wrong because God is true.  Stealing is wrong because God is just.  Hatred and murder are wrong because God is Love.

PRECEPT a PRINCIPLE a PERSON (of God)

Application:  If you filter truth through this method, you will see the vast difference from the popular “they say” verses God’s commands, laws, precepts, and ultimately Himself.  Mediate on Jesus’ words, “To the Jews who had believed him, Jesus said, “If you hold to my teaching, you are really my disciples. 32 Then you will know the truth, and the truth will set you free.”

Blessings
Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Your Wish Or God’s Will, by Brother Boaz Olang

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“…test and approve what God’s will is-his good, pleasing and perfect will”. Romans 12: 2 (NIV).

If you were to choose between the two: having your wish or doing God’s will, what would you choose?

Before you answer this question, you need to understand the meaning of the two words: wish and will and the difference between God’s will and man’s will. Failure to understand the difference will mean incorrect choice. And incorrect choice can result into a conflict, compounded with very severe immediate, subsequent or future consequences. Many people are victims of painful circumstances, frustrations, defeat, depression, confusion, worry, disappointment, failure, and losses, physical and emotional sicknesses etc. because of making incorrect and ungodly choices or decisions for their lives.

What is God’s recommendation? Note the word “recommendation”. God does not impose His will on anyone. He gives us His view, insight to His plans and His word to guide us in making choices. He also expects us to correctly, intelligently, and adequately use our mind to think and reason with Him about every choice or decision we are about to make regarding all areas of our life (Isaiah 1:18). Listen, for example, to what he says in the Bible, regarding making choices and reasoning:

“This day I call heaven and earth as a witness against you that I have set before you life and death, blessing and curses, now choose life, so that you and your children may live and that you may love the Lord your God, listen to His voice, and hold fast to Him. For the Lord is your life and He will give you many years in the land…” Deuteronomy 30:19 (NIV)

“Come now, let us (you and God) reason together,” says the Lord…If you are willing and obedient, you will eat the good from the land; but if you resist and rebel, you will be devoured by the sword.” For the mouth of the Lord has spoken”. Isaiah 1:18-19 (NIV)

These and several verses in the Bible clearly indicate and confirm that knowledge, reasoning and obedience to his voice, are paramount for making decisions and choices that conform to his will and ensures our blessings.

How then can we avoid confusing our wishes with His will? How can we avoid conflict between our wish and His will? How can we escape the temptation of conforming to the world’s standards instead of being transformed by the renewing of our mind by the word of God so we can meet God’s standards?

In life, whenever we are making any choices, we are either choosing God’s will or our wish. That is how life is set to operate. It is unfortunate that many people, including Christians, because of their ignorance due to lack of proper teaching and understanding the meaning of the will of God, do miss God’s best. In addition, confusion and error in judgment are major contributors to missing God’s will.

We operate on wishes most of the time. God operates on His will at all times. We keep a wish list. God keeps a will list. Often, we express our wishes and in some cases insist on them when trusting God to provide for our need. But God insist on His will; it is His will that He approves and appropriates in the lives of His children. Nothing less!

“ Insisting on getting your wishes is a sure guarantee of missing God’s will, for God may grant or permit a wish, without approving of it, for He approves and affirms His will only”.

Why then do we often insist on our wishes? Why is it that often we let our wishes override the will of God? Why is it that when God’s will conflicts with ours, we choose and insist on our wishes? Why do we find it hard to say “Thy will be done” when God cannot give us our wishes? Why is it that we sometimes insist on having our preference and not God’s provision? If God is all knowing and is the supplier of all our needs, why is it  that we refuse, arrogantly, at times, to listen to God’s truth and be convinced so we can accept God’s will? How, then, can one know His will? Why do we often insist on our wishes so we can please ourselves and others instead of accepting God’s will so we can please him, first, and then ourselves? Pray that God will help you know and walk in His will. God bless you. Brother Boaz Olang

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Numbers 13:30, “Then Caleb quieted the people before Moses, and said, “Let us go up at once and take possession, for we are well able to overcome it.”

Have you ever tried to exercise faith in a situation where facts were solid? Facts stared you in the eye, closing every avenue of faith, which would mean seeing beyond facts? Facts are concrete, they are seen, they have evidence, and they have witnesses while on the other hand, faith stands alone defending itself by speaking in away that if only the hearers would dig and see beyond facts and let God’s promises mastered by faith break through facts, then the hearer would have a clear understanding that God’s promises always negates facts which would mean, something can be a fact and not be true.

Moses sent 12 spies in the land of Canaan. There are facts reported in Numbers 13. vs. 27, “…the land … It truly flows with milk and honey, and this is its fruit“. Vs 28, “the people who dwell in the land are strong; the cities are fortified and very large“. They did not need faith to believe the facts; they needed eyes to see it for themselves. One problem, 10 spies only came to stand still when facts stared them in the eye. Facts overwhelmed them that they forgot about the promises of God, which was to be exercised through. They were limited by facts but here comes Caleb who is not denying the evidence of facts, he understands that faith goes beyond facts. His faith is based on the promise God gave to the children of Israel despite what the facts said. He says, “Let us go up at once and take possession, for we are well able to overcome it.” A man of faith ready to exercise faith now in the presence of facts.

Of late I have had facts stare me in the eye giving faith a little or no avenue. Financial challenges are facts along with others but thank God, the promise is enough to generate faith that negates the facts, Hebrews 10:23 “…He who promised is faithful”, Philippians 4:19, “but my God shall supply all your (my) needs according to His riches in glory”, 1Timothy 1:12, “…for I know whom I have believed and am persuaded that He is able to keep what I have committed to Him until that Day”. We need God’s promises through the word building our faith to break through the facts and see the promises being fulfilled. When He gave the promise, He knew there would be facts to challenge faith. The presence of facts is to stretch our faith to believe God  now is He giving us enough faith through His word to challenge facts. What is your situation this morning,? Do you know you have what it takes to challenge facts? Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

James 1:4, “But let patience have its perfect work, that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing”

To walk with God, patience is necessary or else you will not last long with God. As I walk with the Lord, I am learning that God is not in a hurry. If anything, He takes time to do things. Whatever He is doing is not just for today and tomorrow, He is doing it for days to come. He is building His people who will stand through time. I am amazed at how some Christians want things yesterday. They get saved today, tomorrow they are dying to be on talk show teaching everyone how to get saved. Many are anxious to be recognized and entrusted with positions and when it does not happen within their time frame, they get angry and leave. In church if their talents are not recognized, they change churches. Such people do not make it long with God. Why?  They want God to fit in their schedule and that is not going to happen, either you are in His program or you are alone.

Genesis dedicates about 12 chapters on the life of Joseph. It is a vital story that relates to the life of a believer. From the time Joseph receives his dream to the time the dream is fulfilled takes a great deal of process. We shout over the end results but forget that there is a process. When you understand that there is a process, you ready yourself for it. If you want to live a meaningful life, your goal should be large enough to serve as a challenge. Your greatest responsibility is however to do the will of God in the circumstance in which He has placed you as His representative. Whatever you have to accomplish has to have a beginning, you cannot jump to the result without starting from somewhere. Someone once said, “A journey of ten thousand miles begins with a step.” Joseph rejoiced over his end result, even shared it with his family and we all know how it was not received well. God Almighty in His own wisdom knew that this armature would  need work to maintain that dream and develop a character that will keep him even after the dream was fulfilled. I see that God’s main thing in our lives is not so much to deliver us out of situations or give us what we desire, He is in the business of building characters. Character causes one to live in any kind of situations and still shine while in it. Their character changes not with time or positions, it remains intact. Patience is an ingredient that should not miss in a believer’s life.

James 1:4, “But let patience have its perfect work.” James (Jesus half brother) tells us to  let patience do it’s thing; we cannot dictate it, push it, or work it up. It goes in it’s own pace. With patience expect obstacles, barriers, setbacks, walls, and delays. Let it perfect your character through each step, that’s its job. Joseph had his share of struggles, and it wasn’t even clear if the dream would come to pass because of the turn of events but yet he persevered. His responsibility was to persevere in every stage, patience was building his character and God was orchestrating His destiny. David and Job had different experiences that required a lot of patience, God built their characters. “…that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing”. Perfecting something means taking time to work on it, at times things may not go as expected but you stick with it. This is what God is doing with His children, taking them through a process of perfection and completion leaving them lacking nothing. Joseph, David and Job took the class and we read about  their later life, they lacked nothing character wise. If you are frustrated with God because of what He has not done, check to see if you are growing in patience, see how your character is affected by it. When God delays promises, it’s not because the promise needed time to be made, it’s because the person whom He made the promise for was not ready for it. In short, the problem is not with God but with us. There are so many things that I have prayed to God about and now I see why they have not come, I don’t have enough character to support the results yet. I am letting patience do its work,  I don’t want to mess the blessings God will send my way because I had no character. I’m checking in with Dr patience, I need work. I am a patient of patience, what about you?. Blessings Evans

title.rendered: Be Mindful Where You Plant Your Tent- Part 2, by Phil the Evangelist <

content.rendered:
Good morning,

18 aThen Abram moved his tent, and went and dwelt by the terebinth trees of Mamre, which are in Hebron, and built an altar there to the Lord (Genesis 13:18)

Where did Abram plant his tent?  14 And the Lord said to Abram, after Lot vhad separated from him: “Lift your eyes now and look from the place where you are— wnorthward, southward, eastward, and westward; 15 for all the land which you see xI give to you and yyour 3descendants forever. 16 And zI will make your descendants as the dust of the earth; so that if a man could number the dust of the earth, then your descendants also could be numbered. 17 Arise, walk in the land through its length and its width, for I give it to you.”

The Lord mentioned Lot, and saw where Lot chose to plant his tent. However, Abram didn’t choose in and of himself where he would plant his tent.  Notice the Lord said, “Lift up your eyes and look from the place where you are…”  God spoke to Abram and directed his vision, which led to God giving him a promise consisting both of the land and the descendents that would be given to him by the provision of the Lord.  Abram too moved his tent, however he dwelt by the terebinth trees of Mamre.  This was a distinctively large grove of trees owned by Mamre the Amorite (14:13) located ca. 19 mi. SW of Jerusalem at Hebron whose elevation exceeds 3,000 feet. The first thing he did there was to build an altar, which shows he was devoted to the worship of God.  God had already called a wealthy, prosperous, pagan Abram out his land to a place that God would show him.  God was giving Abram land, so he didn’t need to pine for it, and scrape for it.  He generously allowed Lot to make the first choice and have the first move for land.  He didn’t stay and fight for the land, he released it, knowing God was giving him something much greater than he could ever gain by grabbing.  He would simply walk in obedience to God, and walk in the promise of the Father and be given the promised blessing.  Abram was a man that moved by faith.  The writer of Hebrews sheds more light on this as he writes, “8 By faith Abraham obeyed when he was called to go out to the place which he would receive as an inheritance. And he went out, not knowing where he was going. 9 By faith he dwelt in the land of promise as in a foreign country, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise; 10 for he waited for the city which has foundations, whose builder and maker is God (Heb 11:8-10).

Abram walked by faith, not by sight, which was one aspect that set him apart from Lot.  He dwelt in tents because his ultimate home, would be in heaven and not in a tent.  I imagine his attitude was, “For a day in your courts is better than a thousand. I had rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God, than to dwell in the tents of wickedness (Psalm 84:10). Also as the Pslamist said,  “One thing I have desired of the Lord, That will I seek: That I may fdwell in the house of the Lord All the days of my life,     To behold the 2beauty of the Lord, And to inquire in His temple (27:4).”

The ultimate tent dweller however is Jesus.  John writes, “14 sAnd the Word tbecame uflesh and dwelt among us, and vwe beheld His glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father, wfull of grace and truth. When John wrote that Christ “dwelt among us” it literally means “to pitch a tabernacle,” or “live in a tent.”  Deity put on the humanity, and became like us, yet without sin, to reach those dwelling in tents of sin.

1 Tim 3:16 reads, “God was manifested in the flesh, Justified in the Spirit, Seen by angels, Preached among the Gentiles, Believed on in the world, Received up in glory.

Jesus planted his tent among us that He would glorify the Father by coming to reach you and I in our sin.  Thank the Lord for this reality, for otherwise we would dwell in a tent headed for Hell.  “ rDo you not know that you are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God dwells in you? 17 If anyone 2defiles the temple of God, God will destroy him. For the temple of God is holy, which temple you are (1 Cor 3:16).  We should not defile our temple by putting our tents near Sodom, near sin, like Lot.  We must plant our tents in Christ and walk by faith, not by sight, moving where the Lord see’s fit for our lives and not simply where we see fit.  Our tents must be hidden in Christ.

SO WHAT:  Examine your life, and look for any areas that display that you have planted your tent in areas that are not pleasing to the One that planted His tent among us.  May you build an altar before the Lord (find a place alone with the Lord), and read Psalm 139:23-24 making it your prayer and meditating on its truth.

Until the nets are filled…
Phil the Evangelist <><

title.rendered: Be Mindful Where You Plant Your Tent, by Phil the Evangelist <

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Lot dwelt in the cities of the plain and pitched his tent even as far as Sodom (Genesis 13:12).”

Many people say that we are a product of our environment.  It would seem that there is some truth if this is taken as a principle and not as an absolute truth.  We know this because God can take a life that has been influenced by evil all around, and transform that life into something He can glorify Himself through.

Abram prior to having his name changed to Abraham had been called out of Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the Land of Canaan.  Abram was traveling with his nephew Lot, and at some point in their travels together, a problem arose.  The place where this took place was called Bethel, which was an ancient place and seat of worship in Ephraim on border of Benjamin, identified with Luz (former name).  The name Bethel in Hebrew means “house of God.”  Genesis 13:6-7 reads, “ Now the land was not able to support them, that they might dwell together, for their possessions were so great that they could not dwell together. 7 And there was strife between the herdsmen of Abram’s livestock and the herdsmen of Lot’s livestock.” Something had to be done about this problem, so Abram made a decision which would involve separating from his nephew Lot, and parting ways.  “So Abram said to Lot, ‘Please let there be no strife between you and me, and between my herdsmen and your herdsmen; for we are brethren. 9 Is not the whole land before you? Please separate from me. If you take the left, then I will go to the right; or, if you go to the right, then I will go to the left.” This seemed to be a very diplomatic and loving approach to the problem on the part of Abram. It seems that he allowed Lot to make the first choice of where he desired to dwell.  The Bible states that “Lot lifted up his eyes and saw all the plain of the Jordan, that it was well watered everywhere (before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah) like the garden of the Lord, like the land of Egypt as you go toward Zoar.”  Egypt was a prosperous land, but it was also an idolatrous land, full of polytheistic worship, hence they did not worship the one true God.  Abraham and Lot lived in the city of Ur (Gen. 11:28, 31) at the height of its splendor. The city was a prosperous center of religion and industry. The Babylonians worshiped many gods, but the moon god Sin was supreme. Accordingly, the city of Ur was a kind of theocracy centered in the moon deity (New Nelson’s Illustrated Bible Dictionary).”  It would seem that Lot was taken out of Ur, but Ur wasn’t taken out of Lot, and perhaps this is a strong reason why he looked to a place similar to the one he left.  Lot “pitched his tent even as far as Sodom.  But the men of Sodom were exceedingly wicked and sinful against the Lord.”  Paul wrote, “33 Do not be deceived: “Evil company corrupts good habits (1 Cor. 15:33).  Furthermore he writes, “16 rDo you not know that you are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God dwells in you?”  It would seem that Lot pitched his tent (both literally and spiritually) near evil, and his life and his family would certainly be affected by his decision to do so.

Lot would eventually be confronted with the issues of homosexuality, lust, drunkenness, incest, the death of his wife, and the destruction of the land (Sodom) he lived in.  It matters where one plants one’s tent.  I would compare Lot to the foolish man that built his house upon the sand (Matt 7:26-27).  John writes, 19 And this is the condemnation, that the light has come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil (John 3:19). Furthermore he states, “15 Do not love the world or the things in the world. If anyone loves the world, the love of the Father is not in him. 16 For all that is in the world—the desires of the flesh and the desires of the eyes and pride in possessions—is not from the Father but is from the world. 17 And the world is passing away along with its desires, but whoever does the will of God abides forever.  For a day in your courts is better than a thousand. I had rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God, than to dwell in the tents of wickedness (Psalm

84:10).

SO WHAT! Don’t plant your tent (your life) near the wicked.  Don’t desire to live with the wicked, but rather in the house of the Lord.  May you rather be a doorkeeper in the house of God, rather than dwell in tents of wickedness.  Meditate on Psalm chapter 1 and commit it to memory.

Until the nets are filled…Blessings, Phil the Evangelist <><

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Ephesians 5: 15 Be very careful, then, how you live—not as unwise but as wise, 16making the most of every opportunity, because the days are evil. 17Therefore do not be foolish, but understand what the Lord’s will is. (NIV)

We have covered “walking in Love” and “walking in the light”, today, I would like address the third ingredient, “Walking in wisdom”.

I tend to find it hard to distinguish between “knowledge” and “wisdom”. I find that you can have “knowledge” but not “wisdom”, let me qualify my statement. You can have book knowledge but not have wisdom to apply that knowledge. Moreover, if we are going to have a glorious marriage, then we need to have more than just knowledge, we need wisdom to apply the knowledge. God laid in my heart back in November to pray for more wisdom in my life. I have been doing it since then because I need it.

What is wisdom? “Good sense shown in a way of thinking, or action. The ability to make sensible decisions and judgments based on personal knowledge and experience. Wisdom discerns and directs on application.  People mess things up because they are unable to discern (examine, evaluate, understand and approach with wisdom), in Proverbs 9:10, we are told, “The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom, And the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding”. I am amazed at some believers I have met who have zeal but little or no wisdom. They wreck good things because they do not know how to handle it. See how we are told, the fear of the Lord is the “beginning”, it is just a start to gain wisdom, and as we walk and are led of Him, we gain more wisdom that is helpful to us in life.

It is by wisdom as one of the ingredients that a marriage grows. By it we learn our role, our position in our God given marriage. How we treat each other, how we manage family affairs, finances, assets, balancing ministry, and marriage among others are going to depend on how we apply wisdom. It’s  “Through wisdom a house is built, And by understanding it is established” Proverbs 24:3

Paul says, “be very careful, then, how you live—not as unwise but as wise”, lack of wisdom has wrecked a number of marriages. I have heard of cases where a husband confessed that he was the one who wrecked his marriage. He wanted to do good things even had the knowledge but lacked wisdom to pull it through. We have to be very careful how we live and how we treat those we live with.

You can say the right thing but without wisdom it may come out wrong in your tone or presentation. You need to ask yourself, what you want to say, will it come out as disrespectful, demeaning or unloving? We need wisdom in communicating. Are you applying wisdom in how you spend what God gives you? Are you applying wisdom in balancing your work and marriage? You could be working hard to provide excellent living for your family and nothing wrong with that, the question is, “are you out of balance”? neglecting your time with your spouse?. Have you fallen on this trap many believers fall on; too busy serving the Lord, sacrificing your marriage for the sake of your ministry?. Be wise, your marriage is your number one ministry. If you are involved in ministry right now and your marriage is suffering, I would ask you to quit the ministry and go and work on your marriage first. By wisdom, you will know who your enemy is, your spouse is not your enemy. By wisdom you will defend your spouse and not put him or her down. By wisdom you will know who to hang out with knowing there are threats to your marriage, what I would call parasites (that drain you and your marriage), the parasites could be friends or family members. By wisdom, you will not allow those little foxes to devour what is good. By wisdom as Paul says in vs. 16, we will not waste precious time destroying instead of building, “making the most of every opportunity, because the days are evil that is the wise thing to do”. Are you walking in wisdom? Are you wrecking your marriage right now because you lack wisdom? Seek God, read his word, obey the truth and practice what you read, James 1:5, “If any of you lacks wisdom, he should ask God, who gives generously to all without finding fault, and it will be given to him” Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Ephesians 5:8, “For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light 9 (for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, righteousness, and truth), 10 finding out what is acceptable to the Lord”

I outlined three things I believe are key ingredients to a glorious marriage, one walking in love, two walking in the light, and three walking in wisdom. Yesterday we looked at, “walking in love”, today I would like to share on “Walking in the light”

Have you ever tried to find your way in the dark in your house? you walked slowly, stretching your hand to find stuff, trying to use your mind to recall where everything is then suddenly, out of nowhere, your toes find the leg of a piece of furniture?. Ouch!!!, deep cry, movement altered, a few words mumbled, not fun right?

To have a glorious marriage is to walk in the light, Paul says, “We once walked in darkness before we were redeemed,” dashing our toes’ on things of this world, wounding ourselves day by day but now not only are we walking in the light, we are light because Christ glows in us and through us. We ought to treat our spouses as people in the light not only in the presence of everyone but also in your own private time. How many times can you recall fighting on Sunday morning or some other times and you did not feel like being nice to each other that day, you go to church fighting all the way and then nice to each other to show other people things are ok between you.

Read what Paul addressing as signs of a person walking in the light 9 (for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, righteousness, and truth. How do you walk in the light before your spouse, show GOODNESS. Goodness here is, moral excellence, benevolence in thought, word, and deed. Husband, if you are looking at things online you should not, entertaining lustful thoughts, you are not walking in the light before God and your spouse. We need pure thoughts, looking out for God’s daughters who He gave us to care for. We will one day give an account as to how we treated His daughters. So let us thrive to walk in the light without covering things or stone walling. If you are struggling, share with your spouse, be naked and not a shamed (be real). Part of your freedom comes about by being real. Let us be thoughtful in word and deed. Give each other a reason to look forward to coming home, a place where words of encouragements, helping each with responsibilities, leaving kind notes, complimenting, lay down your lives to each other. Be a light unto the young ones who are growing up, neighbors, family members, a demonstration of a glorious marriage ordained by God.

Life of RIGHTEOUSNESS is a life of moral integrity and rightness as God sees it and in relation to man. There are some who are living double lives, not people of their word, living in dishonesty and are not in right standing with God. God will not anoint lies neither will He bless a life that is not real. To walk in the light is to get your act together. God put you in that marriage to refine you and conform you into His image. This is a learning and stretching ground, which will drive you to honor your spouse by living a life that is pleasing to God. A life of integrity, a life of character. If you were asked to do a presentation, would you not put additional effort to work hard to bring the best? How is this not different with marriage, I have a responsibility as a husband to be the best God wants me to be, I have to work hard, learn, grow because someone’s life is in my care. Will that not drive me to live righteously?

To walk in the light is to live in TRUTH, what is truth?, moral reality, honesty, sincerity, and straightforwardness, as opposed to all that is false. How many times do I hear couples say they do not trust each other? Insecurities, spying on each other, always trying to investigate. Where there is no honesty, sincerity or straightforwardness, marriage suffers. Where there is no agreement how will two walks they agree. ?Leaving a truthful life is a challenge but it brings about freedom and unity. We can have glorious marriages when we walk in the light of goodness, righteousness and truth. Examine yourself today, where are you? Are you walking in love and light? Pray to God, let Him show you areas you have compromised, how you have treated your spouse James 5:16, “Confess your trespasses to one another, and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much”. Do not let your prayers be hindered for the sake of issues that have not been dealt with. To continue, blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Tim 4:12, “Let no man despise your youth, but be an example to the believers in word, in conduct, in love, in spirit, in faith, in purity”

I find that mentors are vital people in our lives for growth. People we look up to, people who set up standards that serves as a challenge to get us to the next level. We see it in the bible days, Joshua had a mentor Moses whom he looked up to until the torch was passed over to him. We see also with Elijah and Elisha, the bible describes Elisha as the prophet who washed Elijah’s hand. When Elijah called him to follow him, he kissed everything goodbye including the family business he was running to follow Elijah across the country washing his hands and cooking his meals. If that is not enough, we see it again with Naomi and Ruth, we see how Naomi’s life influences Ruth’s that she is inspired to follow her wherever she went. “Your people shall be my people, your God shall be my God, wherever you will die, I will die there too”, she says. Last but not least we also see it with Paul and Timothy.

I don’t know about you but if I did not have some kind of mentor in my life, I would not be where I am spiritually and even ministry wise. Some did not know that they inspired me until much later when I mentioned to them. Why mentor? If you do not have someone around that challenges you spiritually, or in any other areas, it’s easy to loose your edge the reason being that when you don’t see anything more than what you already have you might feel you have attained it all. I remember when I got saved and then five years later lead into the ministry of intercession, my dad was a huge inspiration without him even knowing in the line of prayers, he has always prayed effectively, earnestly and powerfully. When it came to beginning to preach, I was inspired by one youth pastor back then who has since moved to other positions. I told God that if my youth pastor could preach, I could preach too if He anointed me to do so. I have been preaching since then. God used Pastor Phil to challenge me to reach the lost on the streets, been doing it since then (about 8-9years now). I always struggled to do memory verses until I got inspired and rebuked by someone’s life. He did not tell me or encourage me to do it, the way he memorized verses inspired me to ask God for grace and strength to do it. I believe that there are people who come our way we may not be close to but their life style will cause us to want more. I’m not talking about competition or jealousy, I believe God put such people around us to awaken us by reminding us there is more. If God never allowed me  to come across these people may be I would still be stagnant never knowing there is more I can ask God to do in my life for His glory.

My point today is that it’s good to have certain people come our way, we may not know them or even be close to them but something in their lives will give us an appetite to call on God for more. When Moses died, Joshua took over for he had learnt a lot from Moses and so did Elisha from Elijah, Ruth from Naomi and Timothy from Paul. To close, there are people who God will also bring in our lives who are inspired and challenged by us. Let me share with you about one of my best friends. He was once upon a time, a drug addict, sold drugs, was involved in drive by shootings, arrested about 15 times to mention a few. When he got saved, a few weeks later I was introduced to him and we began to hang out, teaching him the things of God, building his faith.  One time he shared with me how he desired to know how to pray effectively and so I invited him to my prayer nights to come listen and be part of it. Being that he was a new believer, I thought my prayer nights would drive him away. But, he came faithfully, listened to me pray every week and not long after, he started praying little by little. Today he is a prayer warrior, the youth pastor at my church, he preaches in jails and soon he will be opening a troubled teen center. I was his best man, my friend is Pastor Paul. Be an example of believers in every place God sets you, you never know who is taking notes and praying that they will be raised like you are. I believe only you can limit what God can do in your life. God will’s by bringing people your way, then waits for you to respond. Blessings Ev

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Ephesians 5:vs.1 Therefore be imitators of God as dear children. 2 And walk in love, as Christ also has loved us and given Himself for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for a sweet-smelling aroma”

As a little boy with friends we often made our own games and played them, one of the games I remember pretty well was a game we called “cha mama”, this is where we imitated our parents on how they handled their day-to-day activities. We would have a boy play father, a girl play mother; the kids who were a little younger would play the children. We did an excellent job as we tried to imitate what we would see our parents do, how they treated each other, children, responsibilities. We never had a script to act out of, we played along off memories.

Early chapters of Ephesians all the way to chapter 5 prepares us believers. Teaching us how we ought to live. I believe part of it prepares us to be better in our marriages. When you come to chapter 5, there are three things addressed I believe are key ingredients to a glorious marriage 1. Walking in love 2. Walking in the light 3. walking in wisdom. The first thing Paul tells us in vs.1 Therefore be imitators of God as dear children. 2 And walk in love, as Christ also has loved us and given Himself for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for a sweet-smelling aroma”, Unless you are daily cultivating a vertical relationship with the Father of love who teaches you and I what love is, how can you love another person. This is why many girls who never had a father figure in the home find it hard to pick a good husband because they never saw it acted at home. They never had a chance of learning what it means to truly be loved, unconditional love so the world gives them their own version of love. The same for boys who never saw and felt what it means to be loved and in turn learn to give love. How would he do It? We are told to be imitators of God, that vertical relationship is what will drive us to better our horizontal love relationship to our spouses. In remembering how we played games imitating our parents, it later played in life on how I chose and relate to my wife. How do we imitate God, vs. 2 tells us, Walk in love, walking in love means more than saying “I love you” or having warm feelings. Christ loved us and demonstrated that love by giving us Himself as an offering and a sacrifice to God for a sweet smelling aroma. This is sacrificial love

Christ did not give Himself to those who deserved it, He gave Himself because He chose to love us and He did it to the glory of God. If marriage to you is a means to an end, brace yourself for more disappointments for the person you are married to is far from perfection and need work themselves and God will work on you in the process too. The Christian in this case the spouse has no greater calling or purpose than that of imitating Christ our Lord. Christ laid down His life for His bride even when she did not deserve it. This is the kind of love that keeps marriage strong, self sacrificing love that goes beyond faults and weaknesses and looking at the person you are married to and saying something like this, “if Christ has loved you even when you did not deserve it, I will love you because the love of Christ dwells in me”, “I will imitate Christ”

How do we strengthen this love? By protecting it from things that want to diminish in it vs. 3 tells us to put away immorality/adultery (lust), greed, filthiness, foolish talks or coarse joking, deception and give place to thanksgiving which brings about contentment. You have limited growth trying it be what the spouse God wants you to be in your marriage unless daily you commune with Him. You cannot deal and resist the things that want to diminish love unless you are constantly cultivating your vertical relationship. Be in the word, be in prayer and imitate Christ in your marriage. To continue…Blessings Ev

title.rendered: A Husband Enjoying His Wife’s Body, by Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

How beautiful your sandaled feet, O prince’s daughter!  Your graceful legs are like jewels, the work of a craftsman’s hands.  Your navel is a rounded goblet that never lacks blended wine.  Your waist is a mound of wheat encircled by lilies.  Your breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.  Your neck is like an ivory tower.  Your eyes are the pools of Heshbon by the gate of Bath Rabbim.  Your nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking toward Damascus.  Your head crowns you like Mount Carmel.  Your hair is like royal tapestry; the king is held captive by its tresses.   How beautiful you are and how pleasing, O love, with your delights!  Your stature is like that of the palm, and your breasts like clusters of fruit.   I said, “I will climb the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit.” May your breasts be like the clusters of the vine, the fragrance of your breath like apples, and your mouth like the best wine.”  (Song of Solomon 7:1 – 9)

Songs of Solomon or Song of Songs is perhaps one of the most controversial books in Scripture because of its erotic language use.  One camp feels that the book describes ones relationship with the Lord, while the other sees Solomon is sharing his passionate feelings toward his wife, his lover. My personal perspective is that of the later one that this describes passionate, romantic, and erotic love shared between husband and wife.

1.  Start at the Bottom.  Solomon praised his wife starting with her sandaled feet, and then moved to her legs.  Wives enjoy when their husbands notice the little things about them even their feet and legs.  Husbands remember that God brought those feet and legs at one time to you, and you are to keep those feet and legs with you in ONENESS with you.  Praise your wife (not in an idolatrous way) for these features.

2.      Continue in the Middle.  Solomon praised his wife’s navel, waist and breasts.  Many men are drawn away by the mid features of other women, but God desires that our wives be the only source of satisfaction.  Solomon writes is Proverbs 5:19 – 20, “A loving doe, a graceful deer— may her breasts satisfy you always, may you ever be captivated by her love. Why be captivated, my son, by an adulteress? Why embrace the bosom of another man’s wife?  Why not compliment your wife for her mid features today.

3.      Don’t forget the top.  Solomon praised his lover for her neck, hair, eyes, mouth, nose and breath.  When you look at your wife what do you see.  Are you captivated by her beauty?  Are you drawn away by her unique features above her shoulders? Most men are drawn only to those features that are from the waist to the shoulders.  Even Solomon mentioned his wife’s breasts three times.  It seems like he had a thing going on!  However, he shared his intimate words with his wife.  

How beautiful you are and how pleasing, O love, with your delights. “…your breasts like clusters of fruit.   I said, “I will climb the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit.  He described his wife to her from the bottom to top.  He was drawn away, captivated, enamored by her beauty that was for his pleasure and to her delight.  What wife would not like to be complimented by her husband?  Husbands let’s make sure that we are the ones complimenting our wives, because we don’t want someone else to do it for us.  Our wives need to have our voices in their ears praising their beauty and, not another voice.  Have you complimented your wife lately?  Enjoy your wife and let her enjoy you as well.  And perhaps both you and your wife have features that have aged a little.  Remember DON’T TRY and pick another rose just because your petals don’t look like they used to.  Your wife is the rose that God picked for you, so water, shine, and nurture her with your words.  Do you date your wife?  Why not take her out date, like when you first met.  Blessings Pastor Phil

title.rendered: Is There JOY In Your Marriage?, By Pastor Phil

content.rendered:
Good morning,

“Enjoy life with your wife, whom you love, all the days of this meaningless life that God has given you under the sun—all your meaningless days. For this is your lot in life and in your toilsome labor under the sun.”  (Ecclesiastes 9:9)

“You don’t know my wife.”  Perhaps this is a common statement made by many husbands carries the weight of a negative expression.  And perhaps, you’re right, another person doesn’t “know” your wife, but are they supposed to know her like you do?  God has not called anyone except for you to leave and cleave to the woman that you married to.  Marriage is definitely under fire in these days. Hence the statement “you don’t know my wife,” should be an extreme positive and not a negative. Solomon writes of the futility of life, and hence because it is here today and gone tomorrow, one should rejoice in one’s marriage, instead of being depressed in one’s marriage if marriage is done God’s way.  Solomon shares the following points in how one can rejoice in marriage:

    1. Live Joyfully.  This speaks of being full of Joy (JOY-FULLY). Joy is the fruit of being in the presence of the Lord (Psalm 16:11).  Paul writes of the fruit of the Spirit one of which is JOY (Gal. 5:22).  The popular question had been “are you living a purpose driven life,” however I think the better question is, “Are you living a “presence driven life.”  When two people in a marriage are both spending time in the Lord’s presence all that needs to be done is to bring all that JOY together, to live joyfully. Are you and your wife spending DAILY time in His presence?

2.      Relate with Joy together.  The key word here is “WITH”.  God’s desire for marriage is that not only do both husband and wife spend time in the presence of the Lord thus creating a dovetail of like-mindedness, but husbands are privileged to do this WITH their very best friend.  I heard an acronym for J.O.Y., which stood for Jesus Others You!  Jesus must come first, others, in this case your wife is second on the top of the others list, and you are last but not forgotten. 

3.      Love Your Wife. Why did you get married?  People have many reasons, and many which are selfish. Paul however tells us in Ephesians 5, “Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave himself up for her.”  In the Garden of Eden Eve ate the fruit and therefore deserved to die.  God, “Adam I have to kill her.” Adam replied, “No God, please take my life instead.  I will die in her place” Now of course the account didn’t really lay out this way with the first Adam, but it did with the second Adam. Christ gave His life for His beloved bride, and modeled what men are to do for their wives. Jesus said, “No greater love is there than this, that a man lay his life down for his friends.”  Men, our wives are to be our very best friend, and therefore in one word we are to show them love through SACRIFICE!

When one lives JOYFULLY, relates WITH joy together, and loves SACRIFICIALLY, the principle remains that one can live a full life with ones’ life marked by JOY IN MARRIAGE!  Now go live with His Joy in your marriage, it’s really possible! Blessings Pastor Phil`
